courses.name: ADVANCED MONETARY THEORY
courses.desc: A detailed analysis of the foundations of monetary theory. Topics include money in general equilibrium and money and exchange.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B and Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: FINANCIAL ECONOMICS
courses.desc: This course will be concerned with the determination of asset prices. Topics include market efficiency, portfolio choice, derivative securities, and the term structure of interest rates.
courses.anti: Economics 2121A/B, Economics 2181A/B, Economics 2186A/B (if taken 2013-2014, 2014-2015), Economics 2300A/B, Economics 3346A/B, and MOS 3316A/B.
courses.pre:
Economics 2220A/B, Economics 2223A/B, and Economics 2260A/B. 
Pre-or Corequisite(s): Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: TRADE POLICY ISSUES
courses.desc: International trade theory is applied and extended to the international agreements and institutions that form the basis of the international trade system. Topics include: Canada's trade patterns and policies; the role of international trade in developing economies; the evolution of the GATT; and the current problems in international trade.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: CANADIAN ECONOMIC HISTORY
courses.desc: This course takes a topical approach to studying Canadian Economic History. It systematically applies the theoretical principles developed in Economics-341F.G. Topics include fish, fur and lumber; transportation; population/urbanization; Confederation; the wheat boom; the Great Depression; World War II economy; the new Industrialization of the 1950s and 1960s.

courses.name: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT STUDIES
courses.desc: An examination of the causes of economic backwardness and the process of economic development. Topics will include: theories of economic growth and development; role of agriculture; rural- urban migration; development finance; international aspects of development.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B and Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: LABOUR ECONOMICS I
courses.desc: A study of the labour market, including wage and employment determination, labour force participation, investment in labour market skills and unions.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: LABOUR ECONOMICS I
courses.desc: A study of the labour market, including wage and employment determination, labour force participation, investment in labour market skills and unions.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: LABOR ECONOMICS II
courses.desc: Covers topics on the "new labor economics" including economics of discrimination, fertility, marriage, health and crime.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: LABOR ECONOMICS II
courses.desc: Covers topics on the "new labor economics" including economics of discrimination, fertility, marriage, health and crime.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: LABOR ECONOMICS II
courses.desc: Covers topics on the "new labor economics" including economics of discrimination, fertility, marriage, health and crime.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: FINANCIAL MARKETS
courses.desc: Microeconomic theory is applied to Canadian and international financial systems. The focus is on the theory of financial markets and their interaction with the firm sector. Topics include risk and portfolio balance, the capital asset pricing model, the term structure of interest rates, and international financial and foreign exchange markets.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B

courses.name: ECONOMICS OF HUMAN BEHAVIOUR
courses.desc: A survey of economic theories of human behaviour that help to understand economic/social problems such as earnings and education inequality, discrimination, and crime.
courses.anti: Economics 3390F/G if taken prior to Fall 2019.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B, Economics 2223A/B, Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: BEHAVIOURAL ECONOMICS
courses.desc: This course will review recent models and findings in the fields of economics and psychology regarding the errors in human judgment and discuss their importance in an economic marketplace.
courses.pre: Economics 2220A/B, Economics 2222A/B, Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL TRADE
courses.desc: This course explains why nations trade, what are the gains from trade, what determines the pattern of trade, and what are the causes and consequences of various restrictions on trade such as tariffs, quotas, and voluntary export restraints. Foreign investment and the theory of the multinational enterprise are also discussed.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL TRADE
courses.desc: This course explains why nations trade, what are the gains from trade, what determines the pattern of trade, and what are the causes and consequences of various restrictions on trade such as tariffs, quotas, and voluntary export restraints. Foreign investment and the theory of the multinational enterprise are also discussed.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL TRADE
courses.desc: This course explains why nations trade, what are the gains from trade, what determines the pattern of trade, and what are the causes and consequences of various restrictions on trade such as tariffs, quotas, and voluntary export restraints. Foreign investment and the theory of the multinational enterprise are also discussed.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL FINANCE
courses.desc: Topics to be covered include the theory of balance of payments adjustment and the problems of international liquidity.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL MARKETS
courses.desc: An examination of the structure, operation, financial instruments, and recent developments in International Financial Markets. Topics include foreign exchange market mechanics, currency futures, swap, and option markets, and international bond, equity, and money markets.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS
courses.desc: An examination of behavior of firms, market structures, and economic performance. Topics include: how firms compete, the role of entry barriers, innovation and competitiveness, trade and industrial policies, economic regulation and de-regulation, public enterprise, and competition policy.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS
courses.desc: An examination of behavior of firms, market structures, and economic performance. Topics include: how firms compete, the role of entry barriers, innovation and competitiveness, trade and industrial policies, economic regulation and de-regulation, public enterprise, and competition policy.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: EMPIRICAL INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATION
courses.desc: This course introduces students to current research and methods used in the study of empirical questions in Industrial Organization. Answering these questions involves combining theory from microeconomics and tools from econometrics with real data. Topics covered include: demand estimation, methods for measuring market power, price discrimination, and production function analysis.
courses.pre: Economics 2223A/B, and Economics 2260A/B.

courses.name: POLITICAL ECONOMY I
courses.desc: This essay course will provide a survey of major contributions to political economy including voting, the functions of democratic institutions, bureaucracy and dictatorship.
courses.pre: Economics 2150A/B or Economics 2260A/B.

courses.name: INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATION I
courses.desc: An introduction to the modern theory of Industrial Organization. This course introduces the principles of game theory and applies them to the oligopoly problem. It also discusses issues such as: reasons for the existence of firms; the problem of vertical integration; and the incentives for cooperative behavior among firms.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: ECONOMICS AND LAW I
courses.desc: A basic course applying economic theory to the law and to legal and economic institutions. Topics covered include: the evolution and efficiency of property rights; crime and punishment; the modern corporation; torts; contracts; and non-contractual arrangements. No previous knowledge of law is required.
courses.pre: Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL FINANCE
courses.desc: The study of foreign exchange markets and countries' policies towards balance of payments adjustment. Topics include balance of payments accounting, alternative exchange rate regimes, currency markets and hedging, balance of payments adjustment issues, international investment, international liquidity, and the third world debt crisis.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B

courses.name: INTERNATIONAL FINANCE
courses.desc: The study of foreign exchange markets and countries' policies towards balance of payments adjustment. Topics include balance of payments accounting, alternative exchange rate regimes, currency markets and hedging, balance of payments adjustment issues, international investment, international liquidity, and the third world debt crisis.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B

courses.name: MONETARY ECONOMICS
courses.desc: A critical analysis of monetary theory and its applications, including the demand for money, the supply of money, Canadian financial institutions, the Bank of Canada and the conduct of monetary policy.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B

courses.name: MONETARY ECONOMICS
courses.desc: A critical analysis of monetary theory and its applications, including the demand for money, the supply of money, Canadian financial institutions, the Bank of Canada and the conduct of monetary policy.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B

courses.name: NATURAL RESOURCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS
courses.desc: The aim of this course is to develop the economist's approach to environmental problems and natural resource use and to evaluate the effectiveness of various policies that governments have used to solve environmental problems and improve natural resource use.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B and Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: TIME SERIES ANALYSIS AND FORECASTING
courses.desc: This course presents econometrics models and techniques that are widely used in modern time series econometrics. Topics will include uni-route test, integration, co-integration, and forecasting.
courses.pre: Economics 2223A/B

courses.name: APPLIED ECONOMETRICS I
courses.desc: The aim of this course is to give students extended practical experience in applying the techniques studied in Economics 2222A/B and Economics 2223A/B. Topics include data gathering and the use of popular computing packages to estimate the parameters of various static linear models.
courses.pre: Economics 2223A/B.

courses.name: APPLIED ECONOMETRICS II
courses.desc: This course is an introduction to machine learning and big data for use in economic analysis. Machine learning employs techniques for analyzing large data sets with an emphasis on making predictions. The econometric methods covered in Economics 2222A/B and Economics 2223A/B are extended to common machine learning methods such as random forest and artificial neural networks.
courses.anti: Data Science 3000A/B, the former Computer Science 4414A/B, the former Statistical Sciences 3850B, and the former Software Engineering 4460A.
courses.pre: Economics 2223A/B.

courses.desc: An analysis of current topics in Economics.
courses.pre: Economics 2221A/B, Economics 2222A/B, Economics 2261A/B.

courses.name: PERSPECTIVES ON SCHOOLING
courses.desc: This course will consider various perceptions of the purpose and function of schooling, explore the culture of schools, and examine the characteristics and role of the teaching profession. The course is designed for students who are considering a teaching career, and for others interested in the social issues of schooling.

courses.name: EDUCATION AND THE SCIENCES
courses.desc: Three broad themes concerning the nature of science, curriculum, and learning underlie a focus on educational issues in the teaching and learning of the natural and mathematical sciences at the secondary school level. Includes observation in secondary school science classrooms.
courses.pre: Education 2200E.
courses.extra: 2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory (i.e., 3 hr. school observation) per week.

courses.name: SUPPORTING YOUNG CHILDREN TO PLAY MATHEMATICS AND LITERACY
courses.desc: Using postfoundational theories, students consider pedagogies that invite and support young children to encounter, experiment, and engage with literacy and numeracy in ways that honour their lifeworlds and reflect the intentions of pertinent Canadian curricula (e.g., BC's Early Learning Framework, Ontario's How does Learning Happen?).

courses.name: CLASSROOM LEARNING THEORY AND PRACTICE
courses.desc: Classroom Learning Theory and Practice:  A formal discussion of the activities and events of the former Education 2401B, Education 3402B, and Education 4405B -  Professional Practice in Context, including analysis of teaching experiences and critical reflection on the work of teachers in schools.

courses.name: TEACHING & LEARNING IN CONTEXT
courses.desc: Concurrent students participate in a culminating Education program that puts the prior learning of the concurrent program into the context of professional practice.  Course content includes community learning, workshops, seminars, lectures, and professional reflection.  Assignments include an essay on the issues and concerns of professional practice in relation to particular teaching subjects.

courses.name: ELECTRIC CIRCUITS
courses.desc: Basic resistive circuits, Ohm's, Kirchhoff's Laws. DC analyis: nodal and mesh analysis. Network theorems: linearity, superposition, Thévenin's and Norton's theorems. Time-domain analysis: first and second order circuits, source-free and forced response. Sinusoidal steady-state analysis: phasors, complex power. Basic OpAmp circuitry.

Physics 1202A/B or the former Physics 1302A/B or Physics 1402A/B, NMM 1411A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 1411A/B, NMM 1412A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 1412A/B, Engineering Science 1036A/B or Computer Science 1026A/B. 
Corequisite(s): NMM 2270A/B.

courses.name: INTRODUCTION OF VLSI
courses.desc: This course covers fundamentals of semiconductor physics as applied to microelectronics, theory of semiconductor materials and devices. Students will be exposed to basic elements of CMOS circuitry design, including practical implementation of resistors, capacitors, diodes, transistors and MOSFET. Related topics such as delays, cross-talk, parasitics, temperature effects are included.

courses.name: ANALOG COMMUNICATIONS THEORY
courses.desc: This course deals with fundamental principles of wireless RF communications, AM, FM, and PM modulation, demodulation and spectra, and frequency shifting and mixing. Practical linear and nonlinear circuits for a heterodyne radio receiver are studied, including RF/IF amplifiers, matching networks, oscillators, mixers, modulators, demodulators, and phased-locked loops.
courses.pre: ECE 2231A/B, ECE 2233A/B, ECE 3337A/B.

courses.desc:
Selection and investigation of a computer engineering problem. Analytical and/or experimental work is carried out by project groups under the supervision of a faculty member. Progress report and a final engineering report are prepared. Each student must deliver a public oral presentation.

Progress reports and a final engineering report are prepared; each student must deliver a public lecture.

courses.name: ADVANCED DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSING
courses.desc: Digital Signal Processing (DSP) is widely used in speech and audio processing, biomedical engineering, and telecommunication applications. The objectives of this course are to strengthen the students' knowledge of DSP fundamentals, to introduce them to advanced DSP topics, and to familiarize them with the practical aspects of DSP algorithm implementation.

courses.name: RADIATION AND PROPAGATION
courses.desc: EM radiation principles; EM wave propagation, wave polarization, reciprocity theorem, antenna properties, dipole antennas; reflection from the ground; waveguides and transmission lines, impedance matching, antenna arrays, selected topics.
courses.pre: NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B, ECE 3336A/B, ECE 3370A/B.

courses.name: RADIATION AND PROPAGATION

courses.pre: NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B, ECE 3336A/B, ECE 3370A/B.

courses.name: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS
courses.desc: Transceiver design for digital communication systems, design goals and tradeoffs. Deterministic and random signals. Digital modulation techniques, optimal receiver design, performance analysis under noisy conditions. Digital communication through bandlimited channels. Characteristics of wireless channel, intersymbol interference, channel estimation, adaptive equalization. Synchronization techniques. Multiple access techniques, CDMA, TDMA, FDMA. Principles of OFDM, cyclic prefix, in-band pilots, PAPR, applications of OFDM.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3370A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B, NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B.

courses.name: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS
courses.desc: Transceiver design for digital communication systems, design goals and tradeoffs. Deterministic and random signals. Digital modulation techniques, optimal receiver design, performance analysis under noisy conditions. Digital communication through bandlimited channels. Characteristics of wireless channel, intersymbol interference, channel estimation, adaptive equalization. Synchronization techniques. Multiple access techniques, CDMA, TDMA, FDMA. Principles of OFDM, cyclic prefix, in-band pilots, PAPR, applications of OFDM.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3370A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B, NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B.

courses.name: NETWORKING: PRINCIPLES, PROTOCOLS AND ARCHITECTURE
courses.desc: Introduction to networking, network architecture and protocols, layering, OSI and TCP/IP models. Physical layer: transmission media, data encoding, Asynchronous and synchronous transmission. Data link layer: error detection, flow control, error control. Packet Switching: datagrams, virtual circuits, routing, congestion control, internetworking. Local area networks, network layer and transport layer.
courses.pre: Engineering Science 1036A/B or Computer Science 1026A/B.

courses.name: NETWORKING: PRINCIPLES, PROTOCOLS AND ARCHITECTURE

Physical layer: transmission media, data encoding, Asynchronous and synchronous transmission. Data link layer: error detection, flow control, error control. Packet Switching: datagrams, virtual circuits, routing, congestion control, internetworking. Local area networks, network layer and transport layer.
courses.pre: Engineering Science 1036A/B or Computer Science 1026A/B.

courses.name: COMMUNICATIONS THEORY
courses.desc: Introduction to communication systems and information theory. Classification of signals and systems. Communication channel modeling. Fourier series and transform applications. Modulation techniques. Sampling theory and digital transmission. Digital modulation, optimum receiver design, performance analysis. Error control. Selected topics.
courses.pre: ECE 3330A/B, ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3375A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B or Statistical Sciences 2143A/B, NMM 2276A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 2276A/B.

courses.pre: ECE 3330A/B, ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3375A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B or Statistical Sciences 2143A/B, NMM 2276A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 2276A/B.

courses.name: ADVANCED IMAGE PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS
courses.desc: This course explores a few major areas of digital image processing at an advanced level, with primary emphasis on medical applications.  Topics covered include image filtering and enhancement, visualization, image segmentation and image registration. Examples will be presented to give the students exposure to real-world applications in medicine and other applications.
courses.pre: ECE 4445A/B or Medical Biophysics 4445A/B

courses.name: ADVANCED IMAGE PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS
courses.desc: This course explores a few major areas of digital image processing at an advanced level, with primary emphasis on medical applications.  Topics covered include image filtering and enhancement, visualization, image segmentation and image registration. Examples will be presented to give the students exposure to real-world applications in medicine and other applications.

courses.name: CONVENTIONAL, RENEWABLE AND NUCLEAR ENERGY
courses.desc: Global energy resources, distribution and consumption. Sustainability. Principles of operation and control of thermal, nuclear, thermal and hydroelectric, photovoltaic solar and wind power plants. Distributed Generation (DG) and renewable energy technologies. Grid integration of distributed generation.
courses.pre: ECE 3333A/B, MME 2234A/B.

courses.name: CONVENTIONAL, RENEWABLE AND NUCLEAR ENERGY
courses.desc: Global energy resources, distribution and consumption. Sustainability. Principles of operation and control of thermal, nuclear, thermal and hydroelectric, photovoltaic solar and wind power plants. Distributed Generation (DG) and renewable energy technologies. Grid integration of distributed generation.
courses.pre: ECE 3333A/B, MME 2234A/B.

courses.name: INTRODUCTION TO DIGITAL IMAGE PROCESSING
courses.desc: This course covers the fundamentals of digital image processing, including image representation, histograms, contrast enhancement, geometric operations, registration, digital filtering and segmentation. Emphasis is placed on implementation of algorithms and on practical applications in industry, science and medicine.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B

courses.name: INTRODUCTION TO DIGITAL IMAGE PROCESSING
courses.desc: This course covers the fundamentals of digital image processing, including image representation, histograms, contrast enhancement, geometric operations, registration, digital filtering and segmentation. Emphasis is placed on implementation of algorithms and on practical applications in industry, science and medicine.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS
courses.desc: The objective is to examine in-depth the practice of analog and digital communications. Fundamentals of wireless communication electronics are considered. A number of existing systems, including 2G/3G wireless systems, satellite communication systems, radio and TV broadcasting, and others are reviewed. Design aspects of wireless communications systems.
courses.pre:
ECE 3370A/B, ECE 4432A/B, ECE 4437A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B, NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B and completion of the third year of the Electrical Engineering program. 
Corequisite(s): ECE 4433A/B.

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS
courses.desc: The objective is to examine in-depth the practice of analog and digital communications. Fundamentals of wireless communication electronics are considered. A number of existing systems, including 2G/3G wireless systems, satellite communication systems, radio and TV broadcasting, and others are reviewed. Design aspects of wireless communications systems.
courses.pre:
ECE 3370A/B, ECE 4432A/B, ECE 4437A/B, Statistical Sciences 2141A/B, NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B and completion of the third year of the Electrical Engineering program. 
Corequisite(s): ECE 4433A/B.

courses.name: BIOMEDICAL SYSTEMS ANALYSIS
courses.desc: An introduction to biomedical engineering organized around applications of linear and control systems analysis to the dynamics of physiological systems and their responses to diagnostic and therapeutic interventions. Emphasis will be placed on respiratory and cardiovascular physiology and interactions of those systems with medical devices.
courses.pre: (CBE 2221A/B or ECE 2233A/B or ECE 3374A/B or MSE 2233A/B) and (CBE 3310A/B or ECE 3330A/B or MME 3350A/B).

courses.name: BIOMEDICAL SYSTEMS ANALYSIS
courses.desc: An introduction to biomedical engineering organized around applications of linear and control systems analysis to the dynamics of physiological systems and their responses to diagnostic and therapeutic interventions. Emphasis will be placed on respiratory and cardiovascular physiology and interactions of those systems with medical devices.
courses.pre: (CBE 2221A/B or ECE 2233A/B or ECE 3374A/B or MSE 2233A/B) and (CBE 3310A/B or ECE 3330A/B or MME 3350A/B).

courses.name: POWER SYSTEM PROTECTION
courses.desc: To allow students to: a) gain an understanding of the basic principles of protective relays and b) have a practical understanding of protection schemes for electrical power systems and equipment.
courses.pre: ECE 4464A/B

courses.name: POWER SYSTEM PROTECTION
courses.desc: To allow students to: a) gain an understanding of the basic principles of protective relays and b) have a practical understanding of protection schemes for electrical power systems and equipment.
courses.pre: ECE 4464A/B

courses.name: POWER ELECTRONICS
courses.desc: The use of power semiconductor devices in converter structures (topologies) to process and control the flow of electric energy. The aim of the course is to familiarize students with various power electronic converter topologies and their applications.
courses.pre: ECE 2233A/B and ECE 3333A/B.
courses.extra: 3 lecture hours, 1 tutorial hour, 3 hour lab sessions (4 labs per term).

courses.name: POWER ELECTRONICS
courses.desc: The use of power semiconductor devices in converter structures (topologies) to process and control the flow of electric energy. The aim of the course is to familiarize students with various power electronic converter topologies and their applications.
courses.pre: ECE 2233A/B and ECE 3333A/B.
courses.extra: 3 lecture hours, 1 tutorial hour, 3 hour lab sessions (4 labs per term).

courses.name: REAL-TIME AND EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
courses.desc: Review of embedded processors, memory systems, basic peripherals; real-time kernel configurations, task control blocks, interrupt service routines, real-time clocks/timers, multi-tasking, schedulability analysis, inter-task communication, signals, message queues, cooperative/pre-emptive multi-tasking, priority scheduling, priority inversion problems, timing considerations, deadline handing, input-output handling; practical issues in computer control; design, development, and testing techniques.
courses.pre: (Computer Science 1027A/B or Computer Science 1037A/B or SE 2205A/B) and ECE 3375A/B.

courses.name: REAL-TIME AND EMBEDDED SYSTEMS
courses.desc: Review of embedded processors, memory systems, basic peripherals; real-time kernel configurations, task control blocks, interrupt service routines, real-time clocks/timers, multi-tasking, schedulability analysis, inter-task communication, signals, message queues, cooperative/pre-emptive multi-tasking, priority scheduling, priority inversion problems, timing considerations, deadline handing, input-output handling; practical issues in computer control; design, development, and testing techniques.
courses.pre: (Computer Science 1027A/B or Computer Science 1037A/B or SE 2205A/B) and ECE 3375A/B.

courses.name: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS II
courses.desc: Power flow studies; symmetrical faults; symmetrical components; unsymmetrical faults; power system stability; Introduction to High Voltage DC (HVDC) Transmission and Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS).
courses.pre: ECE 3333A/B
courses.extra: 3 Lecture hours/week, 1 Tutorial hour/ week; 1 lab hour/week.

courses.name: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS II
courses.desc: Power flow studies; symmetrical faults; symmetrical components; unsymmetrical faults; power system stability; Introduction to High Voltage DC (HVDC) Transmission and Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS).
courses.pre: ECE 3333A/B
courses.extra: 3 Lecture hours/week, 1 Tutorial hour/ week; 1 lab hour/week.

courses.name: SYSTEMS OPTIMIZATION
courses.desc: Engineering problems as optimization problems. Single-variable optimization. Multi-variable unconstrained optimization. Advanced techniques for unconstrained optimization. Equality and inequality constraints and optimality criteria. Techniques for constrained optimization. Linear programming.
courses.pre: NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B.

courses.name: SYSTEMS OPTIMIZATION
courses.desc: Engineering problems as optimization problems. Single-variable optimization. Multi-variable unconstrained optimization. Advanced techniques for unconstrained optimization. Equality and inequality constraints and optimality criteria. Techniques for constrained optimization. Linear programming.
courses.pre: NMM 3415A/B or the former Applied Mathematics 3415A/B.

courses.name: APPLIED CONTROL SYSTEMS
courses.desc: The course covers analytical methods for analyzing and developing control strategies for industrial processes. These include identification and empirical modeling, tuning of PID controller, digital control systems, z-transformation. PLCs are discussed. Computer based simulation modules using Matlab^® and Simulink^® reused. Examples from different engineering disciplines are studied.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3330A/B as well as successful completion of the third year of the Engineering program

courses.name: APPLIED CONTROL SYSTEMS
courses.desc: The course covers analytical methods for analyzing and developing control strategies for industrial processes. These include identification and empirical modeling, tuning of PID controller, digital control systems, z-transformation. PLCs are discussed. Computer based simulation modules using Matlab^® and Simulink^® reused. Examples from different engineering disciplines are studied.
courses.pre: ECE 3331A/B, ECE 3330A/B as well as successful completion of the third year of the Engineering program

courses.name: MANAGING THE INNOVATION PROCESS
courses.desc: This course targets the essential aspects of building technology-based businesses and how to identify technology innovation capability for use within existing businesses or new start-ups. Students analyze the firm's goals, strengths, weaknesses and opportunities leading to reasonable marketing strategies and action plans. Students learn to make decisions in the face of uncertainty.
courses.pre: Completion of year 2 Engineering or enrollment in year 2 Software Engineering.

courses.name: NEW VENTURE CREATION
courses.desc: This course highlights new venture creation and technology innovation. The entrepreneurial process is introduced as a path to market that includes searching for and screening new ideas, planning development, and starting up new ventures. The course delivery, through the Ivey Business School case method, fosters learning within an active class environment.
courses.anti: Business Administration 4558A/B or the former Engineering Science 3330A/B.
courses.pre: Completion of year 2 Engineering or enrollment in year 2 Software Engineering.

courses.name: ENGINEERING LEADERSHIP
courses.desc: This course develops leadership success skills, providing insight into individual attributes, character and behaviour and how they impact leadership style and approaches. Other critical topics include: vision and leading change, leading through crises, coaching, managing performance, and developing organizational culture.
courses.pre: Completion of year 2 Engineering or enrollment in year 2 Software Engineering.

courses.name: ENGINEERING ETHICS, SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND THE LAW
courses.desc: This course will cover professionalism, ethical theory, the code of ethics and enforcement; the environment; and contracts and risk.
courses.pre: Completion of third year of any Engineering program or registration in Year 3 Integrated Engineering.

courses.name: THE ENTREPRENEURIAL ENVIRONMENT
courses.desc: This course enables students to understand the economic environments in which they will operate as managers and develop focused strategies for an organization to achieve success. Sustainability of initiatives will receive special attention. The course is delivered through the case method, developed by the Ivey Business School to challenge students to learn by doing within an active class environment.
courses.anti: Business Administration 3300K or the former Engineering Science 4481A/B.
courses.pre: Completion of year 2 Engineering or enrollment in year 2 Software Engineering.

courses.name: PROPERTIES OF MATERIALS IN ENGINEERING
courses.desc: An introduction to the relationship between the microstructure and engineering properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, semi-conductors and composites.

courses.name: ENGINEERING STATICS
courses.desc: Analysis of forces on structures and machines, including addition and resolution of forces and moments in two and three-dimensions. The application of the principles of equilibrium. Topics: trusses; frames; friction; and centroids.
courses.extra: 2 lecture hours per week for 10 weeks each term when offered as a Y course; 12 lecture hours per week for 3 weeks when offered as a Summer Intersession course.

courses.name: PROGRAMMING FUNDAMENTALS FOR ENGINEERS
courses.desc: Designing, implementing and testing computer programs using Java and MATLAB to fulfill given specifications for small problems using sound engineering principles and processes. Awareness of the engineering aspects of the process of constructing a computer program.

courses.name: FOUNDATIONS OF ENGINEERING PRACTICE
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles and practices of professional engineering. The design studio fosters innovative thinking, improves problem solving, and provides context. Includes elements of need recognition, conceptualization, prototyping, and engineering design to satisfy commercial specifications. Emphasis on creativity, teamwork, communication and engineering skills necessary to practice in any engineering discipline.
courses.extra: 3 lecture hours per week, 2 lab hours per week and 2 tutorial hours per week.

courses.name: ENGINEERING CO-OP
courses.desc: Provides Engineering undergraduates with a co-operative education placement providing practical professional learning experience. Students are supervised by a practicing engineer and are required to submit performance evaluations and to write a final report on the work performed.
courses.pre: Completion of first year of the Engineering program; good academic standing in the Faculty of Engineering; participation in Co-op Preparation and Training Workshops; full-time course load directly before and after work term.
courses.extra: Non-credit. Eligibility to participate may be impacted by prior scholastic/academic offences.

courses.name: ENGINEERING CO-OP
courses.desc: Provides Engineering undergraduates with a co-operative education placement providing practical professional learning experience. Students are supervised by a practicing engineer and are required to submit performance evaluations and to write a final report on the work performed.
courses.pre: Completion of second year of the Engineering program; good academic standing in the Faculty of Engineering; participation in Coop Preparation and Training Workshops; full-time course load directly before and after work term.
courses.extra: Non-credit. Eligibility to participate may be impacted by prior scholastic/academic offences.

courses.name: MECHANICAL & MATERIALS ENGINEERING EXTERNSHIP PROGRAM I
courses.desc: The Engineering Externship Program provides Engineering Undergraduates with a four month placement at a participating post-secondary institution which offers courses related to a practical Certificate Program.  Completion of ES 2274A/B satisfies the requirements for an Ontario College Local Certificate as defined by Fanshawe College.
courses.pre: Completion of first year of the Engineering program, 60% YWA with no failed courses

courses.name: MME EXTERNSHIP PROGRAM II
courses.desc: The Engineering Externship Program provides Engineering Undergraduates with a four month placement at a participating post-secondary institution which offers courses related to a practical Diploma Program. Completion of ES 2275A/B and its prerequisite satisfies the requirements for an Ontario College Graduate Certificate from Fanshawe College.
courses.pre: Engineering Science 2274A/B.

courses.name: CHEMICAL & BIOCHEMICAL ENGINEERING EXTERNSHIP PROGRAM
courses.desc: The Engineering Externship Program provides Engineering undergraduates, after third year of the Chemical and Biochemical Engineering Option B program, with an eight-month placement at Fanshawe College which offers courses related to a practical Certificate Program.
courses.pre: Completion of third year of the CBE (Biochemical and Environmental Option) program, 70% YWA with no failed courses

courses.name: ENGINEERING IN A GLOBAL CONTEXT
courses.desc: This course exposes undergraduate engineering students to: (i) social and business/industrial culture through lectures and visits to selected cultural sites; (ii) engineering education practices through hands-on experience; and, (iii) state-of-the-art industrial technologies through visits to selected design and production facilities, allowing them to build international linkages facilitating global engagement and to prepare for the competitive worldwide job market.
courses.pre: Completion of first year Engineering and registration in an Engineering program.

courses.name: ENGINEERING CO-OP
courses.desc: Provides Engineering undergraduates with a co-operative education placement providing practical professional learning experience. Students are supervised by a practicing engineer and are required to submit performance evaluations and to write a final report on the work performed.
courses.pre: Completion of penultimate year of Engineering program; good academic standing in the Faculty of Engineering; participation in Co-op Preparation and Training Workshops, full-time course load directly before and after work term.
courses.extra: Eligibility to participate may be impacted by prior scholastic/academic offences.

courses.extra: Eligibility to participate may be impacted by prior scholastic/academic offences.

courses.name: SUMMER COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PLACEMENT
courses.desc: This course will provide engineering undergraduate students with a meaningful placement providing practical professional learning experience in Canada or abroad. Students will be supervised by a practicing engineer and/or suitable aid agency personnel and are required to submit performance evaluations and to write a final report on the work performed. Recognition of this work experience will be indicated by a transcript notation on the student's academic record.
courses.pre: CEE 3327A/B, completion of second year of Civil Engineering Option F.

courses.name: ENGINEERING CO-OP
courses.desc: Provides Engineering undergraduates with a co-operative education placement providing practical professional learning experience. Students are supervised by a practicing engineer and are required to submit performance evaluations and to write a final report on the work performed.
courses.pre: Completion of fourth year of the Engineering program; good academic standing in the Faculty of Engineering; participation in Co-op Preparation and Training Workshops; full-time course load directly before and after work term.
courses.extra: Eligibility to participate may be impacted by prior scholastic/academic offences.

courses.name: GLOBAL EXTERNSHIP FOR ENGINEERS
courses.desc: The objective of this course is to recognize a minimum 12-week international experience (student exchange, volunteer or paid work experience or experiential learning). A number of placement opportunities are accepted as part of this course. Students will prepare a reflective report and make a public presentation based on their experiences in the field. Recognition of this international experience will be indicated by a transcript notation on the student's academic record.
courses.pre: Completion of second year Engineering.

courses.name: ENGLISH FOR ACADEMIC PURPOSES
courses.desc: Combines communication skills through a cross-curricular approach. Students explore complex content from a range of subject areas to gain the foundation required to purposefully read in order to present information and formulate written arguments. Students engage in critical and analytical thinking through readings, and develop listening strategies through class discussions.
courses.pre: Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

courses.name: LITERATURE AND COMPOSITION
courses.desc: This course is designed to introduce the student to the study of literature, including poetry, short stories, novels and plays. The course will encourage a critical approach to literature, with special attention to essay writing skills.
courses.pre: Grade 11U English (or equivalent).

courses.name: POETRY AND DRAMA
courses.desc: This course is designed to introduce the student to the study of literature with a focus on poetry and drama, and may include examples from film. The course will encourage a critical approach to literature, with special attention to essay-writing skills.
courses.pre: Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

courses.name: SHORT STORIES AND NOVELS
courses.desc: This course is designed to introduce the student to the study of literature with a focus on short stories and novels. The course will encourage a critical approach to literature, with special attention to essay-writing skills.
courses.pre: Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

courses.name: THIS UNIVERSITY
courses.desc: Learn about Western, its story, its architecture, academic calendar, governance, codes of conduct, research; and learn about universities, their origins in the Middle Ages, their development and current campus issues. Read a short story by Western’s own Nobel prizewinner Alice Munro, and think about universities in the world today.
courses.pre: Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.
courses.extra: 3 hours. Taught in a flexible hybrid format. May not be used as a prerequisite for modules or upper-year courses in English.

courses.name: UNDERSTANDING LITERATURE TODAY
courses.desc: By studying a broad range of exciting and important literary works from the past and present, this course will increase your understanding and appreciation not just of the richness and power of the works themselves, but also of the role of literature in reflecting and shaping our perceptions of the world and of ourselves.

courses.name: ENRICHED INTRODUCTION TO ENGLISH LITERATURE
courses.desc: This course provides an enriched survey of the major genres, historical periods, and critical approaches to English for students with a particular interest in literature and culture. In lecture and small group tutorials, you will study poetry, prose, and drama with special emphasis on developing superior analytical and writing skills.
courses.pre: 85% or better in Grade 12U English or permission of the Department.

courses.name: FORMS OF FICTION: INTRODUCTION TO NARRATIVE
courses.desc: An introduction to the study of a selection of fiction ranging from the Greek epic to the modern novel, including both short and longer forms; and a variety of fictional modes and narrative techniques. Major authors studied include Homer, Swift, Austen, Dickens, Dostoevsky, and Virginia Woolf.
courses.pre: Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

courses.name: THE STORYTELLER'S ART I: INTRODUCTION TO NARRATIVE
courses.desc: Storytelling defines who we are and our relation to the community, the nation, and the world. This course explores the rich and diverse traditions of storytelling: such as, oral tales, short stories, classic fiction, and graphic novels. Instruction by lecture and tutorials; emphasis on developing strong analytical and writing skills.

courses.name: INTRODUCTION TO LITERATURE: READING, INTERPRETATION, ARGUMENT
courses.desc: This course will examine, both formally and historically, the major generic groupings of literature: poetry, fiction, and drama. Its focus will be on the different kinds of reading that these demand. It will develop students' analytical skills through intensive and extensive reading and through writing that employs logical argument and an understanding of basic critical concepts.
courses.pre: Permission of the Department.

courses.name: FORMS OF NARRATIVE: FROM EPIC TO FILM
courses.desc: An introduction to the study of narrative from the classical epic to contemporary film. Narrative forms such as myth, fable, parable, epic, romance, novel, satire, case-history, short story, and film will be examined in order to understand the distinguishing features of each form, but also the historical development of narrative art.
courses.pre: Permission of the Department.

courses.name: LITERATURE AND CULTURAL REPRESENTATIONS
courses.desc: Combining the study of classic literature with works of current cultural importance, such as graphic novels and film, this course explores how our world and our lives are formed and informed by the stories we tell.
courses.pre: Grade 12U English or permission of the Department.

courses.name: REPRESENTING VIOLENCE: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE STUDY OF ENGLISH LITERATURE
courses.desc: Violence threatens and expresses human culture; it encourages social cohesion and disruption; it is an essential and controversial element of human entertainment. While studying literature which engages with violence, students will develop techniques of close reading and critical analysis, as well as fundamental tools of academic inquiry, research and writing.
courses.pre: Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

courses.name: FOUNDATIONS IN THE NEW LIBERAL ARTS
courses.desc: The English Literature unit of the King's Foundations in the New Liberal Arts is supplemented by the study of art and music. It investigates influential works of literature from ancient to modern times through an interdisciplinary perspective, with special focus on innovations in literary form and cultural contexts.
courses.pre:
Must be registered in the New Liberal Arts, or the former Western Thought and Civilization.
Corequisite(s): History 1901E and Philosophy 1901E.
courses.extra: 3 hours. There may be additional costs associated with field trips.

courses.name: READING POPULAR CULTURE
courses.desc: "If Shakespeare were alive today, he'd be writing for television." This course addresses the many forms of popular culture, including television, music, popular fiction and film, urban myths, and celebrities. The aim of this course is to encourage students to develop a critical understanding of all aspects of popular culture.

courses.name: READING POPULAR CULTURE
courses.desc: "If Shakespeare were alive today, he'd be writing for television." This course addresses the many forms of popular culture, including television, music, popular fiction and film, urban myths, and celebrities. The aim of this course is to encourage students to develop a critical understanding of all aspects of popular culture.

courses.name: READING POPULAR CULTURE
courses.desc: "If Shakespeare were alive today, he'd be writing for television." This course addresses the many forms of popular culture, including television, music, popular fiction and film, urban myths, and celebrities. The aim of this course is to encourage students to develop a critical understanding of all aspects of popular culture.

courses.name: THE CULTURE OF LEADERSHIP I
courses.desc: This course addresses the complex nature of leadership represented in key works of literature and culture, from Malory to Alice Munro, Shakespeare to David Mamet. We will focus on the ethical dilemmas and moral choices faced by leaders to ask what role a leader plays: hero, manager, thinker, strategist, artist, figurehead, authority?

courses.name: THE CULTURE OF LEADERSHIP II
courses.desc: This course examines key cultural works and events that reflect the complexities of group leadership, from Shakespeare to Busby Berkeley, Conrad to Coetzee. We will focus on how various groups and group events - nations, empires, corporations, revolutions, mobs, flash mobs - organize themselves, for better or worse.

courses.name: SCIENCE FICTION AND RELIGION
courses.desc: Though science and religion may seem poles apart, the admixture of physics and metaphysics has a long history in SF, from its originary text, Frankenstein, to such recent SF bestsellers as Robert J. Sawyer's Calculating God. This course will explore the range of ways SF deals with religious themes.

courses.name: GREAT BOOKS
courses.desc: What makes a great book a great book? This survey course offers students a literary world tour of classic novels primarily in English but also in translation, tracing the history and aesthetics of long-form fiction from its roots in the Early Modern period to the present day.
courses.extra:
3 hours.  
NOTE: may not be counted as an elective toward any English module.

courses.name: J.R.R. TOLKIEN, C.S. LEWIS AND FRIENDS
courses.desc: This course explores the fiction of J.R.R. Tolkien (The Lord of the Rings), C.S. Lewis (The Chronicles of Narnia), and their circle in relation to the western literary tradition; genres such as fantasy, science fiction, and detective fiction; and the twentieth-century historical context.

courses.name: THE BLAZING WORLD TO THE HUNGER GAMES: GIRLS, WOMEN, UTOPIA AND DYSTOPIA
courses.desc: The relationship between women and utopia/dystopia can be traced from Margaret Cavendish’s The Blazing World, and extends to tomorrow. This course will explore the history of feminist utopian/dystopian fiction, including works by Cavendish, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Joanna Russ, Ursula K. Le Guin, Marge Piercy, Margaret Atwood, Suzanne Collins, and others.

courses.name: LITERATURE AND FILM
courses.desc: Selected works of literature and film representing a variety of genres and historical-cultural periods are studied to consider how film- makers have adapted literary works into cinema.

courses.name: TOPICS IN LITERATURE AND FILM
courses.desc: Literary and cinematic works studied from a variety of points of view and in a variety of contexts: e.g. narrative, popular culture, genre, period, intertextuality, author/auteur.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS
courses.desc: Please consult Department for current offerings.

courses.name: CHILDREN'S LITERATURE
courses.desc: Readings from significant books written for children, selected primarily for literary quality. Some attention will be given to the historic evolution of "Children's Literature" as a separate class, but the principal aim of the course will be to consider the nature and development of the two major genres: nonsense verse and romance.

courses.name: CHILDREN'S LITERATURE

courses.name: CANADIAN LIT AND CULTURE
courses.desc: An introduction to as many images of our civilization as possible: poetry, prose, fiction, social documentaries, plays, autobiographies. Texts are chosen from works in both English and French (in translation). This material is informally related to our painting, music and films through the use of slides and tapes.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN DRAMA
courses.desc: In this course, students participating in a major Western theatre production explore in theory and practice approaches to text in performance. Only students working as an actor, director, stage manager, assistant stage manager, lighting, set or costume designer may enrol. Permission of the Chair of Undergraduate Studies required to enrol.
courses.anti: English 2041F/G if taken prior to September 2014.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS
courses.desc: Please consult Department for current offerings.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY CANADIAN LITERATURE
courses.desc: An introduction to contemporary Canadian writing in both established and experimental forms. The focus of the course will be on recurrent themes, images, and writing strategies in Canadian writing from 1970 to the present, and on their relationship to both Canadian literary traditions and international currents of thought.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY CANADIAN LITERATURE
courses.desc: An introduction to contemporary Canadian writing in both established and experimental forms. The focus of the course will be on recurrent themes, images, and writing strategies in Canadian writing from 1970 to the present, and on their relationship to both Canadian literary traditions and international currents of thought.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: SCIENCE FICTION
courses.desc: From Mary Shelley's Frankenstein to Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, a consideration of the history and development of science fiction. Will include science fiction themes such as the Other, new technologies, chaos theory, cybernetics, paradoxes of space/time travel, first contact, and alien worlds.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: SCIENCE FICTION
courses.desc: From Mary Shelley's Frankenstein to Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, a consideration of the history and development of science fiction. Will include science fiction themes such as the Other, new technologies, chaos theory, cybernetics, paradoxes of space/time travel, first contact, and alien worlds.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: FANTASY
courses.desc: A study of the purposes and historical origins of fantasy, and modern developments in fantasy: alternate worlds, horror or ghost stories, sword & sorcery, heroic fantasy. May include writers such as Tolkien, Simmons, Peake, Herbert, Beagle, Rowling.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: FANTASY
courses.desc: A study of the purposes and historical origins of fantasy, and modern developments in fantasy: alternate worlds, horror or ghost stories, sword & sorcery, heroic fantasy. May include writers such as Tolkien, Simmons, Peake, Herbert, Beagle, Rowling.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: UTOPIAS AND DYSTOPIAS
courses.desc: An examination of major utopian and dystopian texts. Will concern ways in which humanity has tried to imagine a perfect world, fix the current world, or construct an exaggerated version of the world in order to demonstrate its flaws and weaknesses.

courses.name: SPECULATIVE FICTION: UTOPIAS AND DYSTOPIAS
courses.desc: An examination of major utopian and dystopian texts. Will concern ways in which humanity has tried to imagine a perfect world, fix the current world, or construct an exaggerated version of the world in order to demonstrate its flaws and weaknesses.

courses.name: MYSTERY AND DETECTIVE FICTION
courses.desc: An introduction to the study of popular mystery and detective fiction through the reading of a selection of texts by writers from a variety of national literatures and historical periods, and using a variety of critical approaches. Major authors studied may include Poe, Doyle, Christie, Hammett, Engel, Grafton, Mosley.

courses.name: CULTURES OF BLOOD: THE CONTEMPORARY GOTHIC
courses.desc: Horror has mass appeal, producing a contemporary culture saturated in images of blood for entertainment's sake. This course looks at horror since World War II, primarily in literature but also in film, video, dance, and photography. It asks: what anxieties does horror register? How do monsters reflect what terrifies us?

courses.name: MEDIEVAL HEROES, VILLAINS AND OTHER OUTSIDERS
courses.desc: Many medieval heroes and villains are alive today: Thor, Loki, Beowulf, Joan of Arc, Richard the Lionheart, Eleanor of Aquitaine, Robin Hood, Arthur, Mordred, Hildegard of Bingen, Sylvester II. This course will investigate these real-life and literary figures, considering their construction in medieval texts, and their reconstruction through the ages.

courses.name: THE MADNESS OF CREATIVITY
courses.desc: Students will discuss theories of madness and creativity through works of culture and criticism that are situated historically and culturally. Through examining accepted cultural, social, and ethical norms of thought and behavior, students will gain a deeper understanding of how madness and creativity are critical to our humanness.
courses.anti: Music 3854A/B, Music 3860A/B or English 2190F/G if taken in the winter of 2015-15, 2016-17, 2017-18, 2019-20.

courses.name: THE ALICE MUNRO CHAIR IN CREATIVITY: THE CREATIVE MOMENT
courses.desc: This course, led by the Alice Munro Chair in Creativity, will allow students to explore creativity and its role in the production and study of literature in English and the Arts and Humanities more broadly. See the Department Website for the specific focus of this year’s course.

courses.name: CRIME WRITING SINCE THE 18TH CENTURY
courses.desc:
Literary representations of crime both reflect and influence changing notions of criminality, policing and justice. This course will trace developments in crime writing in English from the 18th century to the present. Among the sub-genres
to be considered are criminal biographies, Newgate novels, detective fiction, true-crime novels, and serial-killer narratives.

courses.name: GLOBAL LITERATURES  IN ENGLISH SURVEY
courses.desc: This course offers students an opportunity to survey links among different literary traditions and innovations across such geographic regions as Asia, Africa, Australia, South America, and the Caribbean. Through close reading of literary texts written in English, students will explore how cultures produce different--often competing--ways of making meaning.
courses.anti: English 2361E, English 2362F/G and English 2363F/G, English 2601E, English 3884E.
courses.pre: Any 0.5 essay course, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TWENTIETH-CENTURY DRAMA
courses.desc: The modern period is marked by social, political, and aesthetic tensions. How does theatre remain relevant amidst these pressures, especially as the stage gives way first to the cinema, then to the TV screen, and now to the internet? We will look at texts spanning 1890 to the present day.
courses.pre: Any 0.5 essay course, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: THE NOVEL
courses.desc: A survey of the novel, chiefly English and American, but including Continental texts, from Cervantes to the present day. Exploration of the nature of this genre is combined with critical examination of each work. It is wise to read as many of the texts as possible before the course begins.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: THE NOVEL
courses.desc: A survey of the novel, chiefly English and American, but including Continental texts, from Cervantes to the present day. Exploration of the nature of this genre is combined with critical examination of each work. It is wise to read as many of the texts as possible before the course begins.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: THE NOVEL
courses.desc: A survey of the novel, chiefly English and American, but including Continental texts, from Cervantes to the present day. Exploration of the nature of this genre is combined with critical examination of each work. It is wise to read as many of the texts as possible before the course begins.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: ADAPTING ACROSS PAGE, STAGE, AND SCREEN
courses.desc: How does the shape an artwork takes contribute to its aesthetic and political power? When artworks flex across form and media how do their messages change? What did Marshall McLuhan mean when he said “the medium is the message”? How do genre and form shape social and political discourse? In this course, students explore these questions and more as they investigate texts that assume multiple cultural forms and represent a diversity of perspectives.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of either English 1020-1999 or Film Studies 1000-1999, or permission of the department.

courses.name: HUMAN RIGHTS AND CREATIVE PRACTICES
courses.desc: Students will examine cultural studies approaches, in national and international Human Rights contexts, to a variety of creative practices including testimony, graphic novels, photography, film and performance. Topics for discussion may include trauma and subjectivity, the representations of atrocity, and the enabling of diversity and empowerment through creativity.
courses.pre: At least 60% in any 1000-level or above “E” or combination of two 1000-level or above “F/G” courses from any department in the faculties of Arts and Humanities, Information and Media Studies (FIMS), or Music, or from the Department of Anthropology, the Department of History, the Department of Political Science, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: SPORT IN LITERATURE
courses.desc: A study of sport as portrayed through works of fiction, non-fiction, short stories and poetry whose central focus is sport. The principal aim of the course is to examine the nature and significance of sport through a survey of sport literature with an emphasis on the novel.
courses.pre: At least 60% in any 1000-level or above “E” or combination of two 1000-level or above “F/G” courses from any department in the faculties of Arts and Humanities, Information and Media Studies (FIMS), or Music, or from the Department of Anthropology, the Department of History, the Department of Political Science, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: LITERARY THEORY: FROM PLATO TO THE NEW CRITICISM
courses.desc: An historical introduction to the theory and criticism of literature. Texts by figures such as Plato, Aristotle, Horace, Augustine, Dante, Sidney, Johnson, Wordsworth, Arnold, T.S. Eliot, Sigmund Freud, Virginia Woolf, Cleanth Brooks and others are considered in relation to such topics as representation, form and structure, history, society, and gender.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: LITERARY THEORY SINCE NEW CRITICISM
courses.desc: A survey of major developments in literary theory since the mid-century. Discussion will deal with texts and ideas associated with such movements as structuralism, feminism, neo-Marxism, post-Freudian psychoanalytical theory, new historicism, deconstruction, postmodernism and post-colonialism.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: SURVEY OF NOTED CATHOLIC AUTHORS
courses.desc: A survey of fiction and poetry by noted Catholic authors from around the world, including in translation. This course focuses on literary engagements with the Catholic tradition of art, architecture, theology, and spiritual practices (such as pilgrimage), as well as with broader social issues, such as decolonization and social justice.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or at least 60% in any 1.0 essay course in any other subject, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: WATER AND CIVILIZATION: LITERATURE, ECOLOGY, ACTIVISM
courses.desc: This course examines non-fictional accounts of the relationship between water (its management and mythology) and the development of diverse civilizations. This course alternates between historical examples from around the world and a specific focus on the Great Lakes Basin, including a group project for improving the ecology of the Thames.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or at least 60% in any 1.0 essay course in any other subject, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: EXISTENTIALIST LITERATURE
courses.desc: An introduction to existentialist literature from its roots in nineteenth century philosophy through its emergence as a major influence on modern and postmodern literature. Selected major philosophical and literary texts from the nineteenth and twentieth century, some in translation, will be covered.
courses.pre: At least 60% in English 1020E, or English 1022E, or English 1024E, or English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or English 1036E.

courses.name: INTRODUCTION TO THEORY
courses.desc: Introduction to the major modes of literary and cultural theory, and the prevailing issues within them pertaining to medium and form, gender and sexuality, race and nation, culture and history.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: CRITICAL PRACTICE
courses.desc: Course Description: This course offers an intensive examination of the major critical methodologies relevant to the academic study of literature. In weekly two-hour lectures and weekly one-hour tutorials that encourage the critical practice of slow reading, students will examine one or more primary literary texts and consider it through a variety of critical lenses.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or Writing 1020F/G or Writing 2101F/G or permission of the Department.

courses.name: BRITISH LITERATURE SURVEY
courses.desc: This course investigates the changing forms of literature produced in the British Isles from the Middle Ages to the present. It addresses key movements and styles through careful analysis of both major authors, such as Shakespeare, Austen, Woolf, or Yeats, and some less well-known yet engaging figures.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: LITERATURE OF THE 16TH CENTURY: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: Introduction to the works of such writers as More, Spenser, Sidney, Marlowe and Shakespeare in relation to the social, political and aesthetic contexts of the time.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: LITERATURE OF THE 17TH CENTURY: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: An introduction to the works of such writers as Donne, Jonson, Herbert, Marvell, and Milton, in relation to the social, political, and aesthetic contexts of the time.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN 17TH CENTURY LITERATURE
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN 18TH CENTURY LITERATURE
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: ROMANTIC LITERATURE: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: Works of representative men and women writers of poetry, fiction, and prose. An introduction to the spirit of a rebellious age and its manifestations in literary art.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN ROMANTIC LITERATURE
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: ENGLISH LITERATURE OF VICTORIAN PERIOD
courses.desc: A survey of selected poetry, fiction, and prose by men and women writers designed to introduce students to the diversity of an age notable for its experimentation in literary forms and subjects, for its defences of individual liberty, and for its affirmations of women's rights.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: VICTORIAN LITERATURE (SURVEY)
courses.desc: A reading of works of poetry, fiction, and prose by representative men and women writers. The course examines continuities with the previous age as well as innovations in literary forms and subjects.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN VICTORIAN LITERATURE
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: BRITISH LITERATURE FROM 1890-1945
courses.desc: Poets such as Hardy, Edward Thomas, Owen, Yeats, Eliot, Auden, and Dylan Thomas; and novelists such as Galsworthy, Lawrence, Joyce, Woolf, Greene and Bowen are read in relation to the major movements and events of the period: Decadence, Symbolism, Imagism, World War I, the Depression, Fascism and World War II.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: BRITISH LITERATURE 1890-1945: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: An introduction to poetry and prose of authors representative of modernism, the literature of the World Wars and inter-war years.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: BRITISH LITERATURE SINCE 1945
courses.desc: Works by post-war and contemporary writers such as Larkin, Amis, Sillitoe, Burgess, Hughes, Fowles, Byatt, Ackroyd, Swift, Heaney and D'Aguiar are studied in relation to the major movements and traditions of 20c literature, but also to post-war social, cultural, and political changes in the U.K.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: BRITISH LITERATURE SINCE 1945: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: An introduction to poets such as Larkin, Hughes, Heaney, and Boland, and novelists such as Fowles, Lessing, Murdoch, and Ackroyd. Discussion will relate the works to social, cultural and political developments in the U.K. from the post-war period to the present.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN BRITISH LITERATURE 1945 TO THE PRESENT
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: J.R.R. TOLKIEN, C.S. LEWIS AND FRIENDS
courses.desc: This course explores the fiction of J.R.R. Tolkien (The Lord of the Rings), C.S. Lewis (The Chronicles of Narnia), and their circle in relation to the western literary tradition; genres such as fantasy, science fiction, and detective fiction; and the twentieth-century historical context.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E; or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G; or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or English 1901E, or permission of the department.

courses.name: AMERICAN LITERATURE FROM COLONIAL PERIOD TO 1890
courses.desc: An introduction to works by some major American authors from the Puritan era to the late 19th century and to some of the significant ideas and techniques in their works. The course explores various aspects of pre-twentieth century American myth-making structures and the attitudes presented by American writers towards prevailing national self-definitions.

courses.name: AMERICAN LITERATURE TO 1890: MAJOR AUTHORS

courses.name: AMERICAN LITERATURE, 1890 TO THE PRESENT
courses.desc: Works by significant 20c American authors will be read in relation to the ways that their ideas and techniques express evolving conceptions of American identity.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: AMERICAN LITERATURE SINCE 1890: MAJOR AUTHORS
courses.desc: An introduction to works by some major American authors from the late 19th century to the present and to some of the significant ideas and techniques in their works.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN AMERICAN LITERATURE: 1890 TO THE PRESENT
courses.desc: This course will focus on a particular author, theme, movement, or literary form from the period.

courses.name: CANADIAN LITERATURE IN ENGLISH SINCE 1914
courses.desc: The study of Canadian literature in English from World War I to the present. Poetry, prose and fiction will be studied in relation to Canadian writers' responses to international modernism, Canadian society during the inter-war and war years, the nationalist movement of the post-war era, and postmodernism.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN 20TH CENTURY CANADIAN LITERATURE IN ENGLISH
courses.desc: This course offers an in-depth study of an author, theme, movement or literary form during the period.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: MONSTERS, GHOSTS AND DEMONS IN THE NINETEENTH CENTURY
courses.desc: This course charts the development of the gothic in English culture in the nineteenth century, including texts by Mary Shelley, Jane Austen, Emily Brontë, Bram Stoker, and Samuel Taylor Coleridge, as well as artwork by William Blake, Henry Fuseli and others. The course will examine historical, theoretical, and artistic contexts.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or English 1901E, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: WORLD LITERATURE WRITTEN IN ENGLISH
courses.desc: An introduction to the international scope of literature written in English. Selected works of fiction, drama, and poetry from a variety of post-colonial societies will be studied in relation to the histories of those societies and the development of the forms.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: POST-COLONIAL WRITING
courses.desc: A selection of significant works from a variety of post-colonial literatures.

Students will encounter a diverse range of genres and authors, from accounts of early explorers to current internationally acclaimed and award-winning writers.

courses.desc: This course offers students a great opportunity to survey of the links between and among  different literary traditions and innovations across such diverse geographic regions as Asia, Africa, Australia, South America, and the Caribbean. courses.desc: An introduction to Biblical and Classical materials that are essential to an understanding of English literature. courses.desc: Students will read texts written for children in order to map changing perceptions of childhood from the 1700s to 1914 - to understand what effects these works were intended to produce, what controversies they generated, and what ideas they embodied about education, adult-child relations, class, nationality, gender and race.

courses.name: CHILDREN'S CULTURE & LITERATURE: THE 1950'S TO THE PRESENT
courses.desc: Students will read texts written for children in order to map changing perceptions of childhood from the 1950s to the present - to understand what effects these works were intended to produce, what controversies they generated, and what ideas they embodied about education, adult-child relations, class, nationality, gender and race.
courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

courses.name: CHILDREN'S CULTURE & LITERATURE: THE 1950'S TO THE PRESENT

courses.pre: At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.
