courses.name: TERRORISM USA
courses.desc: In the wake of 9/11, many Americans seemed shocked that their country was the target of terrorist attacks. They should not have been. This course will explore the history of domestic and foreign terrorist attacks against the US and the many reasons why these attacks were undertaken.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE UNITED STATES IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY
courses.desc: A survey of American history, 1901 to the present, with emphasis upon political, social, and economic developments. Intensive examination of selected topics in seminar.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.
courses.extra: Restricted to Honours Students. 2 lecture hours.

courses.name: THE UNITED STATES IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY
courses.desc: A survey of American history, 1901 to the present, with emphasis upon political, social, and economic developments. Intensive examination of selected topics in seminar.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.
courses.extra: Restricted to Honours Students. 2 lecture hours.

courses.name: THE UNITED STATES IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY
courses.desc: A survey of American history, 1901 to the present, with emphasis upon political, social, and economic developments. Intensive examination of selected topics in seminar.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.
courses.extra: Restricted to Honours Students. 2 lecture hours.

courses.name: LIBERTY IN AMERICA, 1607-2001
courses.desc:
Throughout U.S. history, liberty has been a rallying cry, an individual and collective ambition, a central political ingredient, a religious and a judicial principle, a hope realized and frequently a dream deferred. This course 
examines liberty's multi-dimensional roots from early English settlement (Jamestown, 1607) to the Patriot Act (2001).
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: COLD WAR AMERICA
courses.desc: This course will explore, via case studies, a number of significant social, political, economic, diplomatic and cultural events that defined Cold War America.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: AMERICAN DREAMS: RADICALS AND REFORMERS FROM A "CITY ON A HILL" TO HERLAND
courses.desc:
This course is a critical exploration of American efforts to "begin the world over again." It examines diverse histories of American social reform and experiment, from the 17th through the 20th centuries. Topics include revolutionary millennialism, religious and political radicalism, free thought, literary utopias,
communitarian experiments, abolition, and feminism.

courses.name: IRON-JAWED ANGELS: WOMEN, POWER, AND THE VOTE IN AMERICAN HISTORY
courses.desc:
This seminar course examines American women's suffrage movements in the 19th and 20th centuries, and the consequences of those movements for women's political, social, intellectual, and cultural power. Throughout the course we will pay attention to the intersection of suffrage movements with discourses of
race, region, gender, sexuality, and social justice.

courses.name: AMERICAN SLAVERY, GLOBAL CONTEXT: PROFIT, IDENTITY, AND POWER IN THE MODERN ERA
courses.desc: Students will examine the history and legacies of American slavery by reading awardwinning texts. About half of these readings will recount how slavery emerged and developed in North America, where it was shaped by European, African, and Indigenous societies; other texts will frame slavery in comparative, international, and transnational perspectives.
courses.pre: 1.0 course in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CLASHING EMPIRES IN NORTH AMERICA TO 1800
courses.desc:
Early North American empires (1500-1800), both settler and Indigenous, clashed militarily, socially, and culturally. This comparative course explores various settler societies: New France, New Spain, New England, New Netherlands, Virginia, Pennsylvania, and South Carolina, and their interactions with each other and local Indigenous Nations, to highlight cultural similarities and differences. 

Extra information: 2 seminar hours per week.
courses.pre: 1.0 History course at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: AMERICAN CAPTIVITY NARRATIVES
courses.desc: An examination of American captivity narratives as an historiographical genre. Examples to be studied include colonial-era captivity accounts involving indigenous peoples and white settlers, African American slave narratives, POW memoirs, prison writings, and modern captivity stories. What do these narratives reveal about ethnic, racial, and gender boundaries in America?
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: FRENCH REVOLUTION
courses.desc: An examination of the political, social, economic and religious history of France from 1789 to 1815, and the influence of the French Revolution on Europe.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CRIME AND SOCIETY IN ENGLAND, 1800-1900
courses.desc: This seminar explores nineteenth-century reform of the criminal law: the rise of modern policing and the transformation of both the criminal trial and punishment. It considers the impact of gender and class on definitions of crime and the treatment of offenders as well as the historiography of criminal justice.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CRIME AND SOCIETY IN ENGLAND, 1660-1900
courses.desc: This seminar explores crime and the administration of English criminal justice from the late seventeenth to the end of the nineteenth century. Topics will include the reform of the criminal law, the rise of modern policing, the transformation of prosecution and trial, and developments in penal policy.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE TUDORS AND THE STUARTS: EARLY MODERN ENGLAND
courses.desc: This course considers the Tudor and Stuart dynasties, 1485-1714. Areas covered include the political and religious: how radical was the English reformation, how 'glorious' the revolution of 1688? Cultural topics will also be integral. What rituals dominated people's lives? How riotous were the English?
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: AGE OF EXTREMES: FASCISM, COMMUNISM AND AUTHORITARIANISM IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY
courses.desc: This course examines the crimes, terror, and repression caused in the twentieth century by fascist, communist, and authoritarian regimes in various parts of the world. Topics include Nazi Germany, Stalinist Russia, and non-democratic regimes in post-colonial Asia, Africa and Latin America. Specific themes include the Holocaust, and genocide after 1945.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: SECRETS, SPIES AND SURVEILLANCE IN MODERN BRITISH HISTORY
courses.desc: Britain's culture of secrecy will be examined in both the public and the private spheres through the themes of the Official Secrets Acts, MI5 and MI6, spies and double agents, royalty and the media, birth control, crime investigations, electric monitoring and anti-terrorism laws.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above or permission of the department.

courses.name: VICTORIAN BRITAIN
courses.desc: This course examines dramatic changes and striking contrasts of British society from the early nineteenth century to the First World War. Topics include imperial pageantry, poverty and urban squalor, class rigidity, bold individuality, and the critics of empire.  Students will consider political, social, religious, gender, intellectual and environmental dimensions.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: LONDON UK: CRIME AND DISORDER IN THE 20TH CENTURY
courses.desc: London's people, institutions, culture and geography have been integral to twentieth-century English histories of crime. This course traces broad changes in policing, punishments, crime statistics and popular news reporting, as well as examples of race riots, terrorism, prostitution, forensic science, organized crime, theft, fraud and serial killers.

courses.name: VICTORIAN BRITAIN AND EMPIRE
courses.desc: This course examines dramatic changes and striking contrasts of British society from the early nineteenth century to the First World War. Topics include imperial pageantry, poverty and urban squalor, class rigidity, bold individuality, and the critics of empire. Students will consider political, social, religious, gender, intellectual and environmental dimensions.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE CATHOLIC CHURCH AND THE HOLOCAUST
courses.desc: This course explores the history of the Holocaust from the perspective of Catholic-Jewish relations in Europe from the late 19th century to World War Two. Topics include anti-Judaism and political anti-Semitism, the Catholic Church in Nazi Germany, and Catholic responses to the Holocaust, from collaboration, to resistance and rescue.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above or permission of the department.

courses.name: THE BLACK ATLANTIC: SLAVERY IN THE AMERICAS AND AFRICA
courses.desc:
This course will examine the issues of slavery and slave societies 
within a comparative framework although the main focus of study will be slave systems within Latin America. Themes such as the slave trade, ethnicity, demography, and culture will be explored in order to re-create the context of slave experience.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THREE WORLDS COLLIDE: COLONIAL LATIN AMER SOCIETIES
courses.desc: This course will examine the formative issues that shaped the Latin American Colonial worlds. Relations between ethnicities, genders and classes will be explored to trace the creation of Latin American cultures as African, Indigenous and Europeans came together with explosive force.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE HISTORY OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN LATIN AMERICA
courses.desc: This course explores the long historical development of human rights discourses, advocacy, and abuses in Latin America. It focuses upon the struggle for justice for, and by, indigenous and African populations from contact to the authoritarianism and institutionalized human rights violations of the 20th century.
courses.pre: 1.0 course in History at the 2200 level or above, or permission of the department.

courses.name: SILK ROADS AND SPICE ROUTES: ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL ASIA AND WORLD CONTACTS
courses.desc: This course will investigate the economic, political, religious, cultural, and technological impact of long distance land and sea trade between Asia and other world religions in ancient and medieval times up to around 1500.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: WAR AND MEMORY IN MODERN EAST ASIA
courses.desc: The course analyzes the effects of five crucial wars fought during the period of 1840-1953 in East Asia, especially those of the excesses committed by the dominant armies. It also provides the students with an opportunity to study various interpretations of the events and reflect on war, war crimes, and collective memories.
courses.pre: History 1601E and 1.0 History course numbered 2200 or above; or 2.0 History courses numbered 2200 or above.

courses.name: SEX, LAW, AND SOCIETY IN IMPERIAL CHINA
courses.desc: This course examines state regulation of sexuality in imperial China as manifested in the official treatment of adultery, rape, female chastity, prostitution, and violation of social taboos. It also investigates the life of people excluded from accepted patterns of marriage and family.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above or permission of the department.

courses.name: HISTORY OF WOMEN AND GENDER RELATIONS IN AFRICA
courses.desc: In the past African women were powerful leaders, strong economic contributors and respected members of their extended families. This course will examine these historical roles as well as factors that undermined African women's status and changed gender relations, such as slavery, economic forces and colonialism.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History or Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies, taken at the 2200 level or above if they are History courses or at the 2000 level or above if they are Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies courses.

courses.name: FOREIGN RELATIONS OF THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA
courses.desc: This course will examine the foreign relations of the People’s Republic of China from its inception in 1949 through to the present day. The focus of the course will be on China’s political and security relations with global powers, including the Soviet Union/Russian Federation, Japan, India, Iran, and the USA.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES
courses.desc: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES
courses.desc: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES
courses.desc: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: EUROPEAN IMPERIALISM
courses.desc: This seminar will examine major themes of European Imperialism.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above or permission of the department.

courses.name: CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES
courses.desc: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.
courses.pre: 1.0 course at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERSHIP
courses.desc: This course examines environmental issues in Canada and the United through biography, focusing on leadership by individuals and groups in historical context. Issues include changing ideas of nature, conservation of renewable resources, preservation of habitats, air and water pollution, energy projects, and human health/environmental justice.
courses.pre: Two courses in History or Political Science at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: ENVIRONMENTAL HISTORY
courses.desc: Topics include: the relationship between humans and their environment; ideas on conservation and the environment; the science of ecology; and the history of the conservationist and environmental movements.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: ENVIRONMENTAL HISTORY
courses.desc: Topics include: the relationship between humans and their environment; ideas on conservation and the environment; the science of ecology; and the history of the conservationist and environmental movements.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: FASCISM, NAZISM AND STALINISM COMPARED
courses.desc: This course is a comparative history of Italian Fascism, Nazism and Stalinism. Topics include Marxism and fascism as ideologies, the cultural and social roots of communist and fascist movements, the seizure of power, church-state relations, racial bio-politics, war and political violence, ethnic cleansing, resistance, and authoritarian legacies.
courses.pre: 2.0 senior history courses at the 2200-level or above, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: HISTORIES OF THE CIRCUMPOLAR NORTHS: 'THE LAST IMAGINARY PLACES'
courses.desc: This course examines the circumpolar Norths -  Alaska, Kalaallit Nunaat, Nunavut, Siberia, Saami homelands and more. These regions have long been coveted by resource-hungry southerners and home to "Northerners", Indigenous and otherwise. Coverage includes indigenous lives, southern imperialism, and how various Norths were conceived and re-conceived in the South.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY EXPERIENCE
courses.desc: This research-intensive course provides an examination of selected aspects of the First World War in various combatant nations. Among the themes to be discussed are the alliance system, the experience of battle, home-front conflicts, war culture, gender, strategic and tactical decision-making, and the memory of the war.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE WORLD WARS IN HISTORY, MEMORY AND RECONCILIATION
courses.desc: This course, which concludes with a 10-day program in Belgium and France, explores commemorative practices that emerged after the World Wars. Topics include the presentation of history through monumental architecture, the preservation of battlefields, and museums, and how these sites have informed identity and efforts to reconcile former enemies.
courses.pre: 1.0 History course at the 2200-level or above, and permission of the Department. (Please note, because of the limited enrolment and special circumstances of international travel associated with this course, students will also be interviewed before their registration is finalized.).
courses.extra: 3 hours. Additional cost to be borne by students. Limited enrollment. Application and interview are required. Cross-listed with History 3710F/G.

courses.name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY EXPERIENCE
courses.desc: This course provides an examination of selected aspects of the First World War in various combatant nations. Among the themes to be discussed are the alliance system, the experience of battle, home-front conflicts, war culture, gender, strategic and tactical decision-making, and the memory of the war.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
courses.desc: Students will work individually on an extended research project in the history of the First World War. Themes include engaging with primary documents, presenting research in a conference setting, preparing for publication, and identifying other opportunities for the dissemination of research.
courses.pre: History 4711F/G.

courses.name: SPIRITUALISM, SEANCES AND THE OCCULT
courses.desc: This course explores the popular Spiritualist movement of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, which held that life continued after bodily death and that the spirits of departed souls could be contacted by trained mediums during seances. What certainties did spiritualists hope to discover, and what frauds did their detractors unmask?
courses.pre: 1.0 History course at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: ETHNOHISTORY
courses.desc: Seminar. Selected topics in the history of Amerindian-white relations.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: MASCULINITY AND MODERN HISTORY
courses.desc: This course will introduce students to gender theory generally and masculinity theory specifically. It will also survey critical debates in the history of masculinities while dealing with major themes in modern history.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above or permission of the department.

courses.name: TOPICS IN GENDER HISTORY
courses.desc: A seminar course that examines selected topics to explore the social construction of gender and sexuality in nineteenth and twentieth-century Canada and America.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: WARFARE
courses.desc: Selected topics in the history of warfare.
courses.pre: 2.0 history courses at the 2200 level or above.  Year 3 or 4 Honours Specialization History or Honours Double Major History, or permission of the Department.
courses.extra: 3 hours. This course may be counted as a principal course in the Honours Political Science program. Restricted to Honours Students.

courses.name: EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING
courses.desc: This course places students with agencies and organizations in the community in order to complement classroom learning with experienced-based knowledge of how influence is exercised in public life. Students will work to satisfy both specified learning objectives and placement job requirements.
courses.pre: 1.0 History course at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE AUTOMOBILE AND MODERN CULTURE
courses.desc: This seminar course examines the social impact of the automobile and automotive technology from the late nineteenth century to the present. Technology, industrial design, corporate management styles and the rise of popular automotive culture are among the topics to be examined.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: ENGAGING WITH THE PAST: PRACTICING ACTIVE HISTORY
courses.desc: This course explores the ideas, historiography and practice of active history, an historiographical practice that is responsive to communities of study, the discussion of the work of historians among public audiences. The course examines key themes and the work of prominent historians who have modeled a practice of Active History.
courses.pre: 2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: LETTERPRESS STUDIO
courses.desc: This project-based studio course is a research capstone for students in the History of the Book module.

courses.name: DIGITAL RESEARCH METHODS
courses.desc: In this course students will learn how historical content is produced, presented and published online; how to find and evaluate digital primary and secondary sources; and how to use computational techniques to work with digital resources. No previous background in the subject area is required.
courses.anti: Digital Humanities 2130A/B, Digital Humanities 3902F/G, the former History 2816F/G.
courses.pre: Registration in any academic program at the second-year level or above.

courses.name: SPY VS. SPY
courses.desc: An introduction to close reading and how historians can use the techniques of structured intelligence analysis. Working individually and in groups, students will analyze a series of historical case studies from the 20th and 21st centuries. Topics include espionage, cyber war, terrorism, organized crime, homeland security, counterintelligence, and decision support.
courses.pre: 1.0 History course at the 2200 level or above.

courses.name: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION AND HUMAN RIGHTS
courses.desc: This course explores human rights history, focussing on the language and practice of rights in the French Revolution. Students examine the foundational rights texts of the revolutionary era, and the expansion, limitation, denial of rights for women, religious minorities and people of African origins, enslaved and free, in colonial contexts.
courses.pre: 1.0 course in History at the 2200 level or above, or permission of the department.

courses.name: THE HOLOCAUST AND HUMAN RIGHTS
courses.desc: This course explores the roots of the contemporary human rights movement in the era of Nazism-Fascism and the Holocaust, from the interwar period to the decades after 1945 and the development of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Topics include the role of faithbased organizations as advocates for human rights.
courses.pre: 1.0 course in History at the 2200 level or above, or permission of the department.

courses.desc: The subject will be selected by students in consultation with an instructor of their choice willing to give the course. This course will normally be open only to fourth-year honours students who have achieved an average of at least 80% in their third-year history courses.
courses.pre: Permission of the Department.
