courses.name: EPICUREANS, STOICS AND SCEPTICS
courses.desc: A survey of some main themes in post Aristotelian Greek and Roman philosophy, with an emphasis on Epicurean, Stoic and Sceptical thinkers.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or permission of the department.

courses.name: MEDIEVAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A survey of core issues and figures in medieval philosophy.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G, or 1.0 from Medieval Studies 1022, or both of Medieval Studies 1025A/B and Medieval Studies 1026A/B or the former Medieval Studies 1020E.

courses.name: MEDIEVAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A survey of core issues and figures in medieval philosophy.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G.

courses.name: THOMISTIC PHILOSOPHY II
courses.desc: An advanced course in the philosophy of Thomas Aquinas for those already familiar with his thought. Some later forms of Thomism will also be considered.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2014.

courses.name: LATER MEDIEVAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of selected works by philosophers writing in the high middle ages. Figures to be studied may include Siger of Brabant, Thomas Aquinas, Duns Scotus, and William of Ockham.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G.

courses.name: RENAISSANCE AND REFORMATION PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of later Scholasticism and reactions to it on the part of such figures as Montaigne, Bacon, Melanchthon, John Dee, and the Cambridge Platonists.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: CARTESIANISM AND ITS CRITICS
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of foundational works by philosophers in the Cartesian tradition including study of portions of Descartes's Principles of Philosophy and developments of its themes by such proponents and opponents as Hobbes, Gassendi, Arnauld, and Malebranche.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: CARTESIANISM AND ITS CRITICS
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of foundational works by philosophers in the Cartesian tradition including study of portions of Descartes's Principles of Philosophy and developments of its themes by such proponents and opponents as Hobbes, Gassendi, Arnauld, and Malebranche.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: SPINOZA
courses.desc: A study of the works of Spinoza.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: SPINOZA
courses.desc: A study of the works of Spinoza.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: LEIBNIZ
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of the works of Leibniz. While some themes or works may be focused on to the exclusion of others, this course aims to give students a strong foundational understanding of Leibniz's thought on a range of topics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: LEIBNIZ
courses.desc: An intermediate survey of the works of Leibniz. While some themes or works may be focused on to the exclusion of others, this course aims to give students a strong foundational understanding of Leibniz's thought on a range of topics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: MILL AND MARX
courses.desc: This course is an introduction to John Stuart Mill and Karl Marx, two influential thinkers in modern political philosophy. Marx’s critique of capitalism and Mill’s defence of individual freedom will be critically explored, along with such issues as the proper role of the state and its use of power.
courses.pre: 1.0 course in Philosophy, History or Political Science at the 1000-level.

courses.name: LOCKE
courses.desc: An intermediate study of Locke's Essay concerning human understanding and of related works and correspondence, both by Locke and his critics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: LOCKE
courses.desc: An intermediate study of Locke's Essay concerning human understanding and of related works and correspondence, both by Locke and his critics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: BERKELEY
courses.desc: A study of the philosophical works of George Berkeley, including the works on vision and the De Motu.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: BERKELEY
courses.desc: A study of the philosophical works of George Berkeley, including the works on vision and the De Motu.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: HUME
courses.desc: A study of Book I of Hume's Treatise concerning human understanding supplemented by a study of either Book II and III of the Treatise or a comparative assessment of Hume's work with that of Condillac, Reid, or Kant.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: HUME
courses.desc: A study of Book I of Hume's Treatise concerning human understanding supplemented by a study of either Book II and III of the Treatise or a comparative assessment of Hume's work with that of Condillac, Reid, or Kant.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: THOMAS REID
courses.desc: An intermediate study of 18th-century Scottish Common Sense Philosopher Thomas Reid's work in epistemology, metaphysics, ethics. Topics may include: empiricism; nativism; skepticism; perception; evidence; testimony; language; freedom and responsibility; personal identity; qualities; philosophical method; Reid's defense of Christianity and philosophy of religion; Reid's relations to his predecessors, contemporaries, and successors.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: NIETZSCHE
courses.desc: This course is a survey of Friedrich Nietzsche's philosophical writings, including texts from his early, middle, and late periods. Among the topics to be considered are his critique of Western morality, his doctrine of eternal recurrence, his rejection of the subject, and his declaration of the death of God.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: WOMEN IN EARLY MODERN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: This course is an introduction to the philosophical contributions of women to 17th and 18th Century philosophy. What were their philosophical concerns? How did they influence the course of philosophy during this period? How were their contributions received by their contemporaries and how are they viewed today?
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: THE RATIONALIST TRADITION
courses.desc: A study of efforts in early modern philosophy to place human knowledge, including philosophy, theology, and the sciences, on a rational foundation. The works of Descartes and his successors, such as Malebranche, Spinoza, Leibniz, and others, will be emphasized.

courses.name: THE EMPIRICIST TRADITION
courses.desc: A study of the 17th and 18th century philosophers who argued experience is our primary source of knowledge of reality, and who applied this view to fundamental questions regarding mind, nature, language, and theology. Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Reid, and others will be emphasized.

courses.name: 19TH CENTURY EUROPEAN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A critical, historical and thematic examination of the main currents of 19th century European philosophy including German Idealism and the movements from which Existentialism originated -- forming the background to 20th century European Continental philosophy.
courses.pre: Third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: ORIGINS OF ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An introduction to Analytic philosophy—the revolutionary early 20thcentury reorientation that shaped today’s philosophical landscape and catalyzed intellectual developments from physics to psychology to computer science. Readings explore the "linguistic turn,” the revolt against metaphysics and idealism, logical positivism, ordinary language philosophy, and Quine’s turn to holism and naturalism.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2020, Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X and 0.5 from Philosophy 2260F/G or Philosophy 2400F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: ORIGINS OF ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An introduction to Analytic philosophy—the revolutionary early 20thcentury reorientation that shaped today’s philosophical landscape and catalyzed intellectual developments from physics to psychology to computer science. Readings explore the "linguistic turn,” the revolt against metaphysics and idealism, logical positivism, ordinary language philosophy, and Quine’s turn to holism and naturalism.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2020, Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X and 0.5 from Philosophy 2260F/G or Philosophy 2400F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: FROM HEGEL TO MARX
courses.desc: An examination of the intellectual tradition of 19th century critical philosophy in Germany, including Hegel, Feuerbach and Marx. Topics may include: reason and revolution; labour and alienation; self-activity and liberation; ideology and critique.

courses.name: RECENT CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An examination of themes and figures in European philosophy and critical social theory since the 1960s. Readings are drawn from philosophers and theorists influential in the broad Continental tradition, such as Jacques Derrida, Julia Kristeva, Michel Foucault, Christine Delphy, Jürgen Habermas, Slavoj Zizek, Chantal Mouffe, Alain Badiou, and Silvia Federici.

courses.name: AUGUSTINE
courses.desc: This course discusses Augustine's claim that self-knowledge leads to knowledge and love of God. Ideas examined include the operations of knowing, the character of truth, knowing and doing, the effects of evil, especially pride and self-deception, on knowing, and the relation of knowing to grace and revelation.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: CONFUCIAN THOUGHT
courses.desc: The Confucian Analects present a developing set of insights on transcendence through self-development and participation in cosmic harmony. This course examines the dynamic dialogue that is present among parts of the Analects on these ideas and on relevant unsettled questions that are considered in later Chinese thought.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: BERNARD LONERGAN ON RELIGION AND CULTURE
courses.desc: The Canadian Lonergan's work on knowing and on being presents a possible ground for dialogue among scholars in science, philosophy and theology, and also among believers in various religions. This course examines some of his distinctive notions on the intelligibility of the universe, believe and faith, revelation, love, and hope.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: TOPICS IN EARLY MODERN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 1100E, Philosophy 2202F/G or Philosophy 2206W/X.

courses.name: TOPICS IN MODERN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Later modern philosophy with particular emphasis on the philosophy of the 19th century.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G, Philosophy 2206W/X, Philosophy 3075F/G, or third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: TOPICS IN MODERN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Later modern philosophy with particular emphasis on the philosophy of the 19th century.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G, Philosophy 2206W/X, Philosophy 3075F/G, or third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF LOGIC
courses.desc: study of selected topics from Aristotle to the beginning of the modern period. Topics covered will vary but may include Aristotle's Categories, the theory of the syllogism, medieval theories of signification, the notion of logical consequence, modal logic, and the development of polyadic logic with mixed quantification.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G.

courses.name: TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF ETHICS
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2202F/G or Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF ETHICS
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2202F/G or Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF POLITCAL AND LEGAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2202F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G.

courses.name: TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF POLITCAL AND LEGAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2202F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN LOGICAL THEORY
courses.desc: Specific issues and theories in formal and philosophical logic will be studied.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250 or Philosophy 2252W/X. Students with equivalent background may be admitted by the permission of the department.

courses.name: BIAS, RATIONALITY, AND OBJECTIVITY
courses.desc: Cognitive biases have been found to play a significant role in the thought of individuals and the inquiries of institutional science. Do these results pose a threat to mainstream notions of individual rationality and scientific objectivity? This course will examine some of the epistemological implications of our biased thinking.

courses.name: EVIDENCE, PROBABILITY, AND FACT-FINDING
courses.desc: A study of admissible patterns of reasoning from evidence in making findings of fact. Topics may include: interpretations of probability; the adequacy of Bayesian reasoning in real-life contexts; 'Baconian' (non-mathematical) probability; statistical evidence; evidential weight; expert testimony; eye-witness testimony; relevance. Elements of the law of evidence will be examined.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X, with a minimum grade of 70%.

courses.name: EXPERIMENTAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of recent empirically based criticisms of the traditional practice of consulting a priori intuitions as evidence for and against philosophical theories.

courses.name: THEORIES OF MEANING
courses.desc: Issues and theories in recent philosophy of language. Topics may include: what meaning is; the contrast between "meaning as use" and formalist accounts of meaning; reference and truth. Authors may include: Frege, Russell, Wittgenstein, Strawson and Grice.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2020, Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X or Philosophy 2260F/G.

courses.name: THEORIES OF MEANING
courses.desc: Issues and theories in recent philosophy of language. Topics may include: what meaning is; the contrast between "meaning as use" and formalist accounts of meaning; reference and truth. Authors may include: Frege, Russell, Wittgenstein, Strawson and Grice.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2020, Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X or Philosophy 2260F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY AND LINGUISTICS
courses.desc: Philosophical perspectives on linguistic issues and the science of linguistics. Sample topics: the evidence base for linguistics; what linguistics should take as its proper subject matter; interfaces between syntax, semantics and pragmatics.
courses.pre: Anthropology 1027A/B or French 2806A/B or Linguistics 2288A/B or Philosophy 2020, Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X or Philosophy 2260F/G or Spanish 3303A/B.

courses.name: THE PHYSICS AND PHILOSOPHY OF TIME AND CHANCE
courses.desc: Most observed processes are asymmetric. Cream stirs into coffee but doesn't stir out. This relates to the direction of time: ordered states evolve into disordered states. Thermodynamics expresses this asymmetry and statistical mechanics aims to explain it. This course examines these two theories and the role(s)of probability in physics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2300F/G or Philosophy 2310F/G or permission of the department.

courses.name: PHILOSPHICAL FOUNDATIONS OF QUANTUM MECHANICS
courses.desc: Though quantum mechanics is a well-tested and accepted part of physics, debate continues about what the success of this theory tells us about the world and about science. This course examines these questions while introducing the student to the peculiarities of quantum physics. No physics background presumed.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2300F/G or Philosophy 2310F/G or permission of the department.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN CHINESE PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A special topic in Chinese philosophy will be investigated.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year in a Philosophy module.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN JAPANESE PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A special topic in Japenese philosophy will be investigated.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year in a Philosophy module.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN INDIGENOUS PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A special topic in Indigenous philosophy will be investigated.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year in a Philosophy module.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN ISLAMIC PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A special topic in Islamic philosophy will be investigated.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year in a Philosophy module.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHICAL FOUNDATIONS OF SPACETIME THEORIES
courses.desc: Philosophical issues raised by the physics of space and time: are space and time objectively real or merely abstractions from spatial and temporal relations? Is motion absolute or relative? Is our knowledge of space and time factual or conventional? Authors include: Newton, Leibniz, Kant, Mach, Einstein. No physics background presumed.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2300F/G or Philosophy 2310F/G or permission of the department.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHICAL ISSUES IN EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY
courses.desc: In-depth examination of contemporary philosophical debates arising from modern biology. Topics explored may include the structure of evolutionary theory, the notions of fitness and adaptation, functions and teleological explanation, the ontological status of species, reductionism and levels of explanation, and social and moral implications of biological research.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in the Honours Specialization, Honours Double Major, or Specialization module in Philosophy or permission of the Department.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF BIOLOGY FOR BIOLOGISTS
courses.desc: An introduction to philosophical methods including reading and writing philosophical arguments, followed by five topical modules. Four modules focus on particular fields within the life sciences: evolutionary biology, genetics and genomics, ecology, and cognitive science. A final module examines ethical issues related to research in the life sciences.
courses.pre: Third or fourth year standing in Biology or permission of the Philosophy department.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN ETHICS
courses.desc: A special topic in Ethics will be investigated.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year in a Philosophy module.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF MIND
courses.desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of mind. Topics may include: the metaphysics of mind -- from Cartesian Dualism, through Behaviorism and Identity Theory, to modern functionalist theories; connections between metaphysics of mind and topics such as mental causation, mental content, and consciousness. Emphasis will be given to contemporary readings.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2400F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF PSYCHOLOGY
courses.desc: Conceptual issues arising in psychology. Topics may include: modularity, nativism, theory of mind, the theory theory, simulation theory, concept acquisition, conceptual content. The methodology used by psychologists may also be investigated. Though some historical writings may be used, the emphasis will be on contemporary works.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2400F/G or 3rd year standing in Psychology.

courses.name: INTRODUCTION TO PHILOSOPHICAL ISSUES IN COGNITIVE SCIENCE
courses.desc: An investigation of how neuroscience, artificial intelligence research, linguistics, psychology, and philosophy of mind contribute to our understanding of the mind. Topics may include: the three level analysis, the Turing test, the Chinese Room argument, the classical vs. connectionist debate, computability, genetic algorithms, and dynamical systems.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2260F/G or Philosophy 2400F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G or 3rd year standing in Psychology.

courses.name: MORAL PSYCHOLOGY
courses.desc: Moral psychology is the study of the human capacity for moral thought and behaviour. This course focuses on how philosophers have contributed to debates in moral psychology. Topics may include the roles that reason and emotion play in morality, whether virtue is attainable for us, and our capacity for altruism.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF PERCEPTION
courses.desc: A study of topics in perception such as the status of qualia, sense-datum theories, adverbial theory, phenomenalism, functionalism, representionalism, direct realism, externalist theories of perception, and perceptual belief. Also of the philosophical implications of work on blindsight, interpretations of sensory consciousness, the 'binding problem', and the cerebral localization of consciousness.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2400F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF PERCEPTION
courses.desc: A study of topics in perception such as the status of qualia, sense-datum theories, adverbial theory, phenomenalism, functionalism, representionalism, direct realism, externalist theories of perception, and perceptual belief. Also of the philosophical implications of work on blindsight, interpretations of sensory consciousness, the 'binding problem', and the cerebral localization of consciousness.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2400F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF NEUROSCIENE
courses.desc: Introduction to philosophy of neuroscience. Questions may include: What does neuroscience tell us about the mind-brain relationship, free will and moral responsibility, or the mechanisms of learning and memory? Is consciousness a mental, behavioral or brain state? What is the structure of explanation in neuroscience? Is psychology reducible to neuroscience?

courses.name: EPISTEMOLOGY
courses.desc: Problems in contemporary theory of knowledge. Topics may include epistemic justification, modern skepticism, foundationalism and coherentism, internalism and externalism, ethics of belief, epistemic probability, testimony and social dimensions of knowledge.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: EPISTEMOLOGY
courses.desc: Problems in contemporary theory of knowledge. Topics may include epistemic justification, modern skepticism, foundationalism and coherentism, internalism and externalism, ethics of belief, epistemic probability, testimony and social dimensions of knowledge.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: TRUTH AND PARADOX
courses.desc: Theories of truth since the end of the 19th century, and the problems posed for any theory of truth by the Liar Paradox, with a look at some recent attempts at solutions. Authors may include: Frege, James, Bradley, Ramsey, Tarski, Austin, Strawson, Field, Kripke, Grover, Horwich, Gupta, Soames.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250, or Philosophy 2252W/X, with a minimum grade of 70%.

courses.name: CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An examination of 20th century and contemporary continental philosophy. Readings will be drawn from phenomenological, deconstructive, post-structuralist and feminist texts and/or from the work of the Frankfurt school. Topics to be considered will include some of: intersubjectivity, sexual difference, community, racialization, perception,community, hermeneutics and critical theory.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in a Philosophy module or permission of the Instructor.

courses.name: HUMAN RIGHTS IN SOCIAL POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An advanced reading seminar in Social Political Thought with a focus on Human Rights. Topics will explore the power and philosophical underpinnings that are important to the consideration and establishment of human rights. See the department website for details about the authors and topic being treated in any given year.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year registration in an Honours program, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: HUMAN RIGHTS IN SOCIAL POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An advanced reading seminar in Social Political Thought with a focus on Human Rights. Topics will explore the power and philosophical underpinnings that are important to the consideration and establishment of human rights. See the department website for details about the authors and topic being treated in any given year.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year registration in an Honours program, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: HUMAN RIGHTS IN SOCIAL POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An advanced reading seminar in Social Political Thought with a focus on Human Rights. Topics will explore the power and philosophical underpinnings that are important to the consideration and establishment of human rights. See the department website for details about the authors and topic being treated in any given year.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year registration in an Honours program, or permission of the Department.

courses.name: METAPHYSICS
courses.desc: An introduction to current debate on metaphysical questions. Topics may include the nature of space and time, the status of phenomenal sensible qualities, the existence of natural kinds, causality and determinism, counterfactuals and possible worlds, identity and individuation, and personal identity.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in a Philosophy module or permission of the Instructor.

courses.name: METAPHYSICS
courses.desc: An introduction to current debate on metaphysical questions. Topics may include the nature of space and time, the status of phenomenal sensible qualities, the existence of natural kinds, causality and determinism, counterfactuals and possible worlds, identity and individuation, and personal identity.

courses.name: CAUSALITY
courses.desc: An introduction to metaphysical, epistemological, and logical problems connected with the idea of a cause. Topics may include: the metaphysical nature of the objects related by causality, Humean regularity theories of causation, the necessary condition analysis of causation, probabilistic causality, causes and counterfactuals, and causation in the law.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250 with a minimum grade of 70%.

courses.name: CAUSALITY AND FREEDOM OF  THE WILL
courses.desc: An introduction to the problem posed by the assumptions that human actions are natural occurrences and that natural occurrences are governed by causal laws, whether deterministic or probabilistic. Various versions of determinism, compatibilism, and metaphysical libertarianism will be discussed in connection with ascriptions of legal and moral responsibility.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250 with a minimum grade of 70%, Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: GROUP AGENCY
courses.desc: An examination of the question whether human social groups can have beliefs and intentions and perform actions, where these things are not reducible to the beliefs, intentions, and actions of their individual members; and a consideration of the notion of group accountability. Special attention will be given to corporations.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2801F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF EXISTENTIALISM: ATHEISTIC AND RELIGIOUS APPROACHES
courses.desc: This course focuses on one or more main thinkers or themes in Existentialism, including Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Camus, Marcel, Sartre, and others. We will consider the human condition and situation, freedom, and the responsibility we have for our own lives. Is Existentialism essentially atheistic? How is human freedom reconciled with God?
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: THE PROBLEM OF LOVE
courses.desc: An investigation into some of the central concepts of love from ancient, medieval, and modern thinkers. Special emphasis is placed on questions concerning the nature and role or eros, of agape, and of philia, and whether these different kinds of love can exist together harmoniously.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHICAL THOUGHT OF JOHN PAUL II
courses.desc: A textual analysis and discussion of John Paul II's pre-pontifical and pontifical writings as they pertain to his philosophical thought.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN THE PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION
courses.desc: See department for current offerings.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in Honours Specialization or Major in Philosophy modules.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN THE PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION
courses.desc: See department for current offerings.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in Honours Specialization or Major in Philosophy modules.

courses.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN THE PHILOSOPY OF RELIGION
courses.desc: See department for current offerings.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in Honours Specialization or Major in Philosophy modules.

courses.name: ETHICS
courses.desc: A critical study of moral problems and theories. The course will be based on readings selected from ethical literature from Aristotle to the present.
courses.pre: Third and Fourth Year Honours standing in a Philosophy Program or Module.

courses.name: METAETHICS
courses.desc: Metaethics is the area of moral philosophy in which we inquire about, among other things, the status of moral claims, the meaning of moral terms, the rational justification of morality, the nature of value, and issues of moral psychology. This course is an advanced study of topics in metaethics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: METAETHICS
courses.desc: Metaethics is the area of moral philosophy in which we inquire about, among other things, the status of moral claims, the meaning of moral terms, the rational justification of morality, the nature of value, and issues of moral psychology. This course is an advanced study of topics in metaethics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G.

courses.name: NORMATIVE ETHICS
courses.desc: Moral philosophers engaged in normative ethics seek to articulate and justify systems of normative standards - of action or of character - to guide our moral life. This course is an advanced study of normative ethical theories, such as utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue theories.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: NORMATIVE ETHICS
courses.desc: Moral philosophers engaged in normative ethics seek to articulate and justify systems of normative standards - of action or of character - to guide our moral life. This course is an advanced study of normative ethical theories, such as utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue theories.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: RESEARCH ETHICS
courses.desc: An introduction to ethical issues in human experimentation, covering ethical frameworks for research ethics, informed consent, confidentiality, benefit-harm analysis, participant selection, and vulnerable participants and communities. Special topics, such as randomized controlled trials, gene therapy trials, cluster randomized trials, and health policy and systems research may also be covered.
courses.extra:
3 hours.
Philosophy 2715F/G is recommended, but not required.

courses.name: EMBODIMENT
courses.desc: An investigation of the philosophical implications of corporeal existence. Topics include: bodily autonomy; dependence and vulnerability; transhumanism; racialization and colonized bodies; sexed difference; reproduction; the commodification of biological material; and relationships between subjectivity, selfhood, corporeality, and identity.

courses.name: JUSTICE
courses.desc: A seminar in political and legal philosophy. Sample topics: the distinction between corrective and distributive justice, the use of class actions as a mechanism of social justice, the redistribution of wealth through taxation, the role of constitutional institutions in delivering and embodying justice, and conceptual models of a just society.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: JUSTICE
courses.desc: A seminar in political and legal philosophy. Sample topics: the distinction between corrective and distributive justice, the use of class actions as a mechanism of social justice, the redistribution of wealth through taxation, the role of constitutional institutions in delivering and embodying justice, and conceptual models of a just society.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: GLOBALIZATION AND THEORIES OF JUSTICE
courses.desc: This course subjects globalization, as an economic, political and cultural phenomenon, to critical scrutiny, using tools provided by theories of justice. Topics considered may include: sweatshops; world hunger; refugee rights; the claim to universality in human rights discourse; and the ethics of militant protest to back demands for global justice.

courses.name: ADVANCED PHILOSOPHY OF FOOD
courses.desc: An exploration of the deep philosophical roots of the normative challenges facing our food system and our relationships to food. Issues may include the sources and justifications for capitalism, the nature of corporations, communitarianism, sustainability, social and economic classism, social justice, and nature and roles of intuitions in structuring society.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2082F/G or the former Philosophy 2010F/G or the former Philosophy 3010F/G.

courses.name: CASE STUDIES IN BUSINESS ETHICS
courses.desc: A seminar course involving the extended examination of major real-world cases in business ethics. Sample areas for examination: pharmaceuticals, the automotive industry, mining, the petroleum industry.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2074F/G.

courses.name: CLIMATE JUSTICE
courses.desc: Climate change affects everyone, but its burdens fall unevenly on different people, depending on factors like race and class. In responding, many Indigenous, environmentalist, anti-racist, feminist and labour movements speak of climate justice. What is climate justice? How might it impact the law, public policy and social movements?

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF SOCIAL SCIENCE
courses.desc: A survey of a number of core philosophical questions raised in and about the social sciences, for example: Can, and ought, the social sciences aspire to objectivity? Is the goal of the social sciences explanation, prediction, understanding, prescription or some combination? Is social life governed by laws?
courses.pre: Third year or fourth year standing in a module in Philosophy or in a Department in the Faculty of Social Science.

courses.name: SOCIAL CONSTRUCTION OF INSTITUTIONS
courses.desc: An exploration of social ontology, examining a range of questions about the nature of social reality. Topics considered may include: social norms, statuses, roles and institutions; the social construction of race, gender and other identities; collective intentionality; collective goods; interactive kinds; and the distinction between system and life-world as forms of social integration. Readings may include works by several contemporary philosophers, including Sally Haslanger, Ian Hacking, John Searle, Jürgen Habermas, and Charles Taylor.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2500F/G, or 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN SOCIAL POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An advanced reading seminar in Social Political Thought. See the department website for details about the authors and topic being treated in any given year.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy or Social Political Thought program.

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN SOCIAL POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An advanced reading seminar in Social Political Thought. See the department website for details about the authors and topic being treated in any given year.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy or Social Political Thought program.

courses.name: AESTHETICS
courses.desc: An investigation of issues in the philosophy of art and aesthetics. Topics include: characteristics of the various arts; the fine arts, arts and cultures, mass arts; art, craft, and technology; beauty, taste, and the variety of aesthetics; freedom and self-expression; individuals and cultures; mimesis and imagination; interpretation and audience participation.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: AESTHETICS
courses.desc: An investigation of issues in the philosophy of art and aesthetics. courses.pre: Third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy or registration in the Diploma in Art Therapy Program.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A seminar devoted to the investigation of selected philosophical problems as they arise in the writings of such philosophers as Moore, Russell, Ayer, Carnap, Quine, Wittgenstein, Ryle, Wisdom, Austin, and others.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2250 or Philosophy 2252W/X. Students with equivalent background may be admitted by the permission of the department.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY ANALYTIC PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A seminar devoted to the investigation of selected philosophical problems as they arise in the writings of such philosophers as Moore, Russell, Ayer, Carnap, Quine, Wittgenstein, Ryle, Wisdom, Austin, and others.

courses.name: CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An exploration of the main questions raised in twentieth century European philosophy. Beginning with Husserl's challenge to subject/object dualism, topics covered will include history, alterity, embodiment, temporality, spatiality, intentionality, intersubjectivity, human agency, and sexual difference, as examined by such authors as Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Foucault and Irigaray.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth Year Honuors Philosophy status or the former Philosophy 2554E.

courses.name: TOPICS IN CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of selected topics in continental philosophy. The topics dealt with vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY CONTINENTAL SOCIAL AND POLITICAL THOUGHT
courses.desc: An investigation of central figures and concepts in 20th century Continental European social and political thought. Questions to be investigated: the nature of power, the roles and nature of the state, the construction of subjectivity, feminism, and the legacy of genocide.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: HEIDEGGER
courses.desc: A critical reading of the philosophy of Martin Heidegger.
courses.pre: Third and Fourth Year Honours standing in a Philosophy Program or Module.

courses.name: SEMINAR IN ANCIENT PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Third and Fourth Year Honours standing in a Philosophy Program or Module.

courses.name: ADVANCED SEMINAR ON MARCUS AURELIUS' MEDITATIONS
courses.desc: A close reading and critical discussion of the Stoic emperor's work. Topics include his cognitivist theory of emotions, his urge to live the present moment in the fullest, the tension between determinism and freedom. How can Marcus' unique solutions positively influence both our everyday life and the therapy of emotions?
courses.pre: Philosophy 2200F/G or Philosophy 2205W/X, or by permission of the Department.

courses.name: HISTORY OF THE PHILOSOPHY OF RACE
courses.desc: Among the innovations credited to the thinkers of the early Modern period, perhaps the most infamous is the invention of the concept of race. In this course we will consider the treatments of race by prominent philosophers (Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant), and look at a variety of related discussions including the monogenesis/polygenesis debate and the rise of "scientific" racism.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN THE HISTORY OF PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of selected philosophical problems as they have been dealt with over time. The problems and historical periods covered vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN THE HISTORY OF PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of selected philosophical problems as they have been dealt with over time. The problems and historical periods covered vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: SEMINAR ON KANT
courses.desc: Extra Information: 3 hours.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2202F/G and third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN PHILOSOPHY OF LANGUAGE
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in the philosophy of language.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2260F/G.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN THE PHILOSOPHY OF SCIENCE
courses.desc: A study of a selected topic in the philosophy of science. The topics dealt with vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN THE PHILOSOPHY OF SCIENCE
courses.desc: A study of a selected topic in the philosophy of science. The topics dealt with vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: SYNTHETIC BIOLOGY AND PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: Introduction to synthetic biology and to philosophical questions relating to it. These include: is synthetic biology revolutionary? Can it help us gain a better understanding of life? What are the ethical dimensions of creating genetic novelty in various contexts? Some background in bioethics and/or philosophy of science is recommended.

courses.name: WOMEN AND SCIENCE
courses.desc: The course focuses on the intersection between scientific knowledge and women. We consider the historical and sociological contexts that prevented women from accessing and producing scientific knowledge. We then discuss the questions at the center of the feminist reflection on science and the different perspectives produced in the feminist epistemologies.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN PHILOSOPHY OF MIND
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in the philosophy of mind.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2400F/G.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN EPISTEMOLOGY
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in epistemology.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: EPISTEMOLOGY
courses.desc: Full year course in basic problems of epistemology. Readings from contemporary writings will be stressed.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2260F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G or third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: TOPICS IN FEMINIST THEORIES OF KNOWLEDGE
courses.desc: A critical study of contemporary feminist epistemology and philosophy of science, with discussion of feminist empiricism, standpoint, and postmodern positions, critiques of methodological essentialism, and proposals for integrating the consideration of contextual factors into theories of knowledge production and legitimation.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: PHENOMENOLOGY
courses.desc: 20th century phenomenologists developed and practiced methods by which they could access and describe the nature of reality. Students will engage with such phenomenologists (e.g., Husserl, Heidegger, Stein, Merleau-Ponty, Sartre) in order to analyze questions concerning the nature of being and consciousness, freedom, time, space, subjectivity and intersubjectivity.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN METAPHYSICS
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in metaphysics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2500F/G.

courses.name: METAPHYSICS
courses.desc: Full year course in basic problems of metaphysics. Readings from contemporary writings will be stressed.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2300F/G or Philosophy 2500F/G, or third or fourth year honours standing in Philosophy.

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN PRACTICAL ETHICS
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in practical ethics.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: TOPICS IN FEMINIST ETHICS AND SOCIAL/POLITICAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An intensive study of central themes in feminist ethics and social/political theory. Topics include: feminist critiques of classical and contemporary theories of moral agency, autonomy, and individualism; constructive proposals for feminist alternatives to the ethics of rights; arguments for contextualizing ethical and social/political theory.
courses.pre: 3rd or 4th year standing in a Philosophy program.

courses.name: TOPICS IN PHILOSOPHY OF GENDER AND SEXUALITY
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of topics arising in the philosophy of gender and sexuality.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in the Honours Specialization, Honours Double Major, or Specialization module in Philosophy or permission of the Department.

courses.name: GENDER AND RACE
courses.desc: This course deals with various types of philosophical questions about gender and race, including metaphysical, epistemological, political, and ethical questions. The goals are to analyze how philosophers have approached these questions, and in doing so, take seriously how gender and race intersect with one another.

courses.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN POLITICAL PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of a particular problem arising in political philosophy.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2700F/G or Philosophy 2800F/G or Philosophy 2801F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: THEORIES OF PROPERTY
courses.desc: An examination of Aristotelian/Thomistic , Lockean/libertarian, utilitarian, Kantian, and Hegelian theories of property.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2800F/G, or Philosophy 2821F/G, or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: CONTEMPORARY ISSUES IN THE PHILOSOPHY OF PROPERTY
courses.desc: An examination of contemporary issues concerning property such as: taxation and redistribution, eminent domain, intellectual property, limitations on development, commodities and commodification.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2800F/G, or Philosophy 2821F/G, or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW
courses.desc: Advanced seminar on issues of legal theory, varying from year to year.
courses.pre: Any Faculty of Law course or Philosophy 2080 or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW
courses.desc: Advanced seminar on issues of legal theory, varying from year to year.
courses.pre: Any Faculty of Law course or Philosophy 2080 or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW
courses.desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of law.
courses.pre: Any Faculty of Law course or Philosophy 2080 or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW
courses.desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of law.
courses.pre: Any Faculty of Law course or Philosophy 2080 or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW: FREE SPEECH ON CAMPUS
courses.desc: A close look at Canadian and American ideas about constitutional freedom of speech and expression, and their applications to issues that arise on university campuses. Topics will include: harassment, hate speech, controversial political speech, controversial research publication, religious and anti-religious speech, social media, and sexual and gendered speech.
courses.pre: Any Faculty of Law course or Philosophy 2080 or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G or permission of the instructor.

courses.name: TRADITIONAL AND CONTEMPORARY NATURAL LAW
courses.desc: An examination of Aquinas's version of natural law theory, with a consideration of contemporary natural law theories reflections of in his views. Authors may include: Richard Hooker, John Finnis, Germain Grisez, Joseph Boyle, Robert George. Particular public policy issues, such as abortion, the regulation of sexuality, and same-sex marriage, may also be discussed.
courses.pre: Philosophy 2201F/G or Philosophy 2821F/G or Philosophy 2822F/G.

courses.name: HONOURS CAPSTONE: SEMINAR
courses.desc: This seminar will introduce students to contemporary philosophical research. Students will read and present on material recently published in the instructor's areas of expertise. Students will be guided through the process of identifying paper topics that could contribute to active research in philosophy.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in the Honours Specialization in Philosophy.

courses.name: HONOURS CAPSTONE: COMMUNITY ENGAGED LEARNING
courses.desc: Students will apply their philosophical skills outside the classroom through a Community Engaged Learning (CEL) experience. Through project-based partnerships with community groups selected by or for students, they will use their philosophical talents to contribute to their community partner’s mission and learn for themselves how philosophy can impact daily life.
courses.pre: Third or Fourth year standing in the Honours Specialization in Philosophy.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of selected philosophical problems. The problems vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.

courses.name: PROBLEMS IN PHILOSOPHY
courses.desc: A study of selected philosophical problems. The problems vary from year to year. More detailed information concerning content and prerequisites may be obtained from the Department prior to registration.
